  • Pass arguments inside parentheses if needed: functionName(arg1, arg2)

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
function add(a, b) {
  return a + b;
}

let result = add(10, 20);
console.log(result); // 30

docs.title: ✅ Summary
docs.text:
• Function Declaration: Named, hoisted, reusable.
  • Function Expression: Anonymous or named, assigned to a variable.
  • Call a function: functionName()
  • Return values: Can return integers, arrays, or other data types.
  • Default parameters: Provide fallback values.
  • Hoisting: Declarations are hoisted, expressions are not.

Functions are fundamental building blocks for organizing and reusing code in JavaScript.

docs.title: 🚀 JavaScript Promises — From Simple to Real-Time Complex Examples
With Playwright-Like Use Cases + Console Outputs
docs.text: This guide takes you from simple → intermediate → real-time complex Promise usage so you understand how Promises actually help in real testing or backend flows.

docs.title: 1️⃣ Simple Promise (Basic Understanding)
docs.text:
const simpleTask = new Promise((resolve) => {
  setTimeout(() => {
    resolve("Simple Task Done!");
  }, 1000);
});

simpleTask.then((msg) => console.log("Output:", msg));

✅ Output

arduino
Copy code
Output: Simple Task Done!

docs.title: 2️⃣ Intermediate Example — Multiple Promises (Promise Chaining)
docs.text:
function step1() {
  return new Promise((resolve) => {
    setTimeout(() => resolve("Step 1 completed"), 1000);
  });
}

function step2() {
  return new Promise((resolve) => {
    setTimeout(() => resolve("Step 2 completed"), 1000);
  });
}

function step3() {
  return new Promise((resolve) => {
    setTimeout(() => resolve("Step 3 completed"), 1000);
  });
}

step1()
  .then((res1) => {
    console.log(res1);
    return step2();
  })
  .then((res2) => {
    console.log(res2);
    return step3();
  })
  .then((res3) => console.log(res3));

✅ Output

Copy code
Step 1 completed
Step 2 completed
Step 3 completed

docs.title: 3️⃣ Real-Time Example — Calling API With Promises
docs.text:
(Useful for Playwright API testing)

javascript
Copy code
function getUserData() {
  return fetch("https://jsonplaceholder.typicode.com/users/1")
    .then(response => response.json());
}

getUserData().then((data) => {
  console.log("User Name:", data.name);
});

✅ Output

Copy code
User Name: Leanne Graham

docs.title: 4️⃣ Complex Example — Run Tasks in Parallel
docs.text:
(Real-Time Use Case: Fetch multiple APIs or run multiple operations simultaneously)

const fetchUser = () =>
  new Promise((resolve) => {
    setTimeout(() => resolve("User Fetched"), 1500);
  });

const fetchOrders = () =>
  new Promise((resolve) => {
    setTimeout(() => resolve("Orders Fetched"), 1000);
  });

const fetchPayments = () =>
  new Promise((resolve) => {
    setTimeout(() => resolve("Payments Fetched"), 2000);
  });

Promise.all([fetchUser(), fetchOrders(), fetchPayments()])
  .then((results) => {
    console.log("All tasks completed:");
    console.log(results);
  });

✅ Output

All tasks completed:
[ 'User Fetched', 'Orders Fetched', 'Payments Fetched' ]

docs.title: 5️⃣ Complex Example — Promise.race()
docs.text:
const fast = new Promise((resolve) => setTimeout(() => resolve("Fast API"), 500));
const slow = new Promise((resolve) => setTimeout(() => resolve("Slow API"), 2000));

Promise.race([fast, slow]).then((result) => console.log("Winner:", result));

✅ Output

Winner: Fast API

docs.title: 6️⃣ Complex Example — Retry Mechanism With Promises
docs.text:
(Real-Time: Retry API/network calls)

function fetchWithRetry(retries = 3) {
  return new Promise((resolve, reject) => {
    const success = Math.random() > 0.5; // Random fail/success

    console.log("Trying API…");

    if (success) {
      resolve("API Success!");
    } else if (retries > 0) {
      console.log("Retrying…");
      return resolve(fetchWithRetry(retries - 1));
    } else {
      reject("API Failed after retries");
    }
  });
}

fetchWithRetry()
  .then((res) => console.log(res))
  .catch((err) => console.log(err));

Possible Output

mathematica
Copy code
Trying API…
Retrying…
Trying API…
Retrying…
Trying API…
API Success!

OR

nginx
Copy code
Trying API…
Retrying…
Trying API…
Retrying…
Trying API…
API Failed after retries

docs.title: 7️⃣ Real-Time Playwright-Style Example — Custom Wait Using Promises
docs.text:
function waitForElement(selector) {
  return new Promise((resolve) => {
    const check = setInterval(() => {
      const el = document.querySelector(selector);
      if (el) {
        clearInterval(check);
        resolve("Element found: " + selector);
      }
    }, 200);
  });
}

waitForElement("#login-button").then((msg) => console.log(msg));

Example Output

Element found: #login-button

docs.title: 8️⃣ Real-Time Example — Playwright Test Simulated With Promises
docs.text:
function navigateTo(url) {
  return new Promise((resolve) => {
    console.log("Navigating to:", url);
    setTimeout(() => resolve("Page Loaded"), 1000);
  });
}

function clickButton() {
  return new Promise((resolve) => {
    console.log("Clicking Login Button");
    setTimeout(() => resolve("Button Clicked"), 500);
  });
}

function validateHomePage() {
  return new Promise((resolve) => {
    console.log("Validating Home Page");
    setTimeout(() => resolve("Home Page Validated"), 800);
  });
}

async function runTest() {
  const pageLoad = await navigateTo("https://example.com");
  console.log(pageLoad);

  const click = await clickButton();
  console.log(click);

  const validate = await validateHomePage();
  console.log(validate);

  console.log("Test Completed");
}

runTest();

Output

Navigating to: https://example.com
Page Loaded
Clicking Login Button
Button Clicked
Validating Home Page
Home Page Validated
Test Completed

docs.title: JavaScript Promises --- Complete Guide (Beginner to Advanced)
docs.text: This is an extended version with extra explanations for every code snippet, making it easier to understand each concept deeply.

docs.title: 1. What Are Promises?
docs.text:
A Promise is a JavaScript object that represents the result of an asynchronous operation.

Asynchronous operations include: - Loading a webpage\ - Reading a file\ - Waiting for a timer\ - Calling an API\ - Browser actions in Playwright

Because these tasks take time, JavaScript needs a way to continue running other code while waiting. Promises make this possible.

docs.title: A Promise has 3 states:
docs.text:
State Meaning

Pending The async task has started but not finished Resolved/Fulfilled The task completed successfully Rejected The task failed

docs.title: Example:
docs.text:
let p = new Promise((resolve, reject) => {
  // Promise started → pending state
  resolve("Success!");
});

docs.title: Explanation:
docs.text:
• When the Promise is created, it is pending.
  • After resolve("Success!") runs, it becomes fulfilled.
  • If reject("error") was called, it would become rejected.

docs.title: 3.1 .then() --- Handle Success
docs.text:
p.then(result => {
  console.log(result);
});

docs.title: Explanation:
docs.text:
• .then() runs only when the Promise resolves.
  • result contains "Success!".

docs.title: 3.2 .catch() --- Handle Errors
docs.text:
p.catch(error => {
  console.log("Error:", error);
});

docs.title: Explanation:
docs.text:
• .catch() runs when a Promise rejects.
  • Example errors: network failure, invalid operation, timeouts.

docs.title: 3.3 .finally() --- Always Runs
docs.text:
p.finally(() => {
  console.log("Task complete!");
});

docs.title: Explanation:
docs.text:
• .finally() always runs whether resolved or rejected.
  • Useful for cleanup operations: closing browser, clearing cache, etc.

docs.title: Full Example With All Three
docs.text:
let p = new Promise((resolve, reject) => {
  setTimeout(() => resolve("Loaded!"), 2000);
});

p.then(res => console.log(res))
 .catch(err => console.log(err))
 .finally(() => console.log("Done"));

docs.title: Explanation:
docs.text:
• After 2 seconds, Promise resolves with "Loaded!".
  • .then() prints the result.
  • .finally() prints "Done" no matter what.
  • .catch() would only run if an error occurred.

docs.title: 4. async/await --- Modern Way of Using Promises
docs.text: The async/await keywords make asynchronous code look like synchronous code.

docs.title: Example:
docs.text:
async function loadData() {
  try {
    const result = await p;
    console.log(result);
  } catch (err) {
    console.log("Error:", err);
  } finally {
    console.log("Finished");
  }
}

docs.title: Explanation:
docs.text:
• async tells JavaScript that this function contains asynchronous code.
  • await p pauses execution until the Promise p resolves.
  • try/catch gives cleaner error handling than .then().catch().
  • finally executes at the end.

docs.title: 5.1 Promise.all()
docs.text:
Runs multiple Promises in parallel and waits for all to complete.

const p1 = new Promise(res => setTimeout(() => res("1 done"), 1000));
const p2 = new Promise(res => setTimeout(() => res("2 done"), 2000));

const result = await Promise.all([p1, p2]);
console.log(result);

docs.title: Explanation:
docs.text:
• p1 resolves in 1 sec.
  • p2 resolves in 2 sec.
  • Promise.all() waits for both to finish.
  • Output will be: ["1 done", "2 done"].

If any Promise fails, the whole thing fails.

docs.title: 5.2 Promise.race()
docs.text:
Resolves or rejects as soon as any one Promise completes.

const p1 = new Promise(res => setTimeout(() => res("First!"), 1000));
const p2 = new Promise(res => setTimeout(() => res("Second!"), 2000));

const result = await Promise.race([p1, p2]);
console.log(result); // First!

docs.title: Explanation:
docs.text:
• p1 resolves first → result becomes "First!".
  • p2 is ignored.

Useful when waiting for the fastest response (e.g., backup servers, timeouts).

docs.title: 6. How Playwright Uses Promises Internally
docs.text:
Playwright interacts with a real browser, and real-world browser actions take time.

So every Playwright method returns a Promise:

await page.goto("https://google.com"); 
await page.click("#loginButton");
await page.waitForResponse("**/api/login");

docs.title: Explanation:
docs.text:
• page.goto() waits for the webpage to load.
  • page.click() waits until the click action is complete.
  • page.waitForResponse() waits until an API completes.

These operations are asynchronous by nature, so Promises are required.

docs.title: 7. Real Playwright Testing Examples That Use Promises
7.1 Clicking + Navigation (Promise.all)
docs.text:
await Promise.all([
  page.waitForNavigation(),
  page.click("text=Login")
]);

docs.title: Explanation:
docs.text:
• Navigation and clicking happen together.
  • Without Promise.all, Playwright may miss the navigation event.

docs.title: 7.2 Waiting for API calls
docs.text:
const [response] = await Promise.all([
  page.waitForResponse(res => res.url().includes("cart")),
  page.click("#addToCart")
]);

console.log(await response.json());

docs.title: Explanation:
docs.text:
• Waits for both the button click and the API response.
  • Avoids flakiness due to race conditions.

docs.title: 7.3 Iterating Locators (Each click returns a Promise)
docs.text:
const items = page.locator(".menu-item");
const count = await items.count();

for (let i = 0; i < count; i++) {
  await items.nth(i).click();
}

docs.title: Explanation:
docs.text:
• Each .click() is asynchronous.
  • Loop ensures items are clicked in sequence.
  • Without await, clicks may happen out of order.

docs.title: 8. Custom Promise Utility
docs.text:
A common use case: waiting for some time in tests.

function wait(seconds) {
  return new Promise(resolve => {
    setTimeout(() => resolve("Done"), seconds * 1000);
  });
}

await wait(2);
console.log("Finished!");

docs.title: Explanation:
docs.text:
• Creates a custom Promise using setTimeout.
  • Useful for demo/testing async behavior.
  • (Not recommended for actual Playwright waits --- use built-in waits.)

docs.title: 9. Summary Table
docs.text:
Feature Description

Promise Object representing an async task Promise States Pending → Fulfilled → Rejected then() Runs on success catch() Runs on error finally() Always runs async/await Cleaner syntax for promises Promise.all() Wait for multiple tasks Promise.race() Return first completed Playwright All actions return promises

docs.title: 🎉 END OF EXTENDED PROMISES GUIDE
docs.text: This file now includes deeper explanations, step-by-step logic, and fully commented code for real-world understanding.

docs.title: 1. What is an Object?
docs.text:
An object in JavaScript is a collection of key-value pairs. Objects are used to store structured data.

const person = {
  name: "Nitin",
  age: 25,
  city: "Pune"
};
  • Keys are also called properties
  • Values can be string, number, boolean, array, function, or another object

docs.title: 2. Nested Objects
docs.text:
Objects can have other objects as values (nested objects).

const person = {
  name: "Nitin",
  age: 25,
  city: "Pune",
  address: {
    street: "MG Road",
    zip: 411001,
    state: "Maharashtra"
  }
};

docs.title: Accessing Nested Properties
docs.text:
console.log(person.address.street);  // MG Road
console.log(person["address"]["zip"]); // 411001

docs.title: 3. Adding Functions in Objects
docs.text:
Objects can have methods (functions as values):

const person = {
  name: "Nitin",
  greet: function() {
    console.log("Hello, " + this.name);
  },
  greetES6() {
    console.log(`Hello, ${this.name}`);
  }
};

person.greet();   // Hello, Nitin
person.greetES6(); // Hello, Nitin

docs.title: Add New Property
docs.text:
person.country = "India";
person["language"] = "English";

docs.title: Update Existing Property
docs.text: person.age = 26;

docs.title: Delete Property
docs.text: delete person.city;

docs.title: 5. Checking if Property Exists
docs.text:
"name" in person;               // true
person.hasOwnProperty("city");  // false (if deleted above)

docs.title: Using for...in loop
docs.text:
for (let key in person) {
  console.log(key, person[key]);
}

docs.title: Using Object Methods
docs.text:
// Keys
Object.keys(person); // ["name", "age", "country", "language", "greet", "greetES6"]

// Values
Object.values(person); // ["Nitin", 26, "India", "English", f, f]

// Entries
Object.entries(person);
/*
[
  ["name","Nitin"],
  ["age",26],
  ["country","India"],
  ["language","English"],
  ["greet", f],
  ["greetES6", f]
]
*/

docs.title: 7. Nested Objects and Arrays
docs.text:
const person = {
  name: "Nitin",
  hobbies: ["reading", "coding", "travelling"],
  address: {
    city: "Pune",
    history: [
      { year: 2019, city: "Nagpur" },
      { year: 2020, city: "Delhi" }
    ]
  }
};

console.log(person.hobbies[1]);             // coding
console.log(person.address.history[1].city); // Delhi

docs.title: 8. Summary Table
docs.text: Operation Syntax Example Create simple object const obj = { key: value } { name: "Nitin", age: 25 } Create nested object obj = { key: { nestedKey: value } } { address: { city: "Pune" } } Add property obj.newKey = value person.country = "India" Update property obj.key = newValue person.age = 26 Delete property delete obj.key delete person.city Add function (method) obj.method = function(){} person.greet = function(){} Access property obj.key or obj["key"] person.name Loop through object for...in for(let k in person){ console.log(k, person[k]); } Get keys Object.keys(obj) Object.keys(person) Get values Object.values(obj) Object.values(person) Get entries Object.entries(obj) Object.entries(person)

docs.title: 3. Operators in JavaScript – Deep Dive
docs.text: JavaScript provides a variety of operators to perform operations on values and variables. Operators can be categorized as Arithmetic, Assignment, Comparison, Logical, Bitwise, and Ternary.

docs.title: 🔹 Arithmetic Operators
docs.text:
Used to perform mathematical operations.

Operator Description + Addition - Subtraction * Multiplication / Division % Modulus (remainder) ** Exponentiation ++ Increment -- Decrement

docs.title: Examples – Arithmetic
docs.text:
let a = 10;
let b = 3;

console.log(a + b);  // 13
console.log(a - b);  // 7
console.log(a * b);  // 30
console.log(a / b);  // 3.3333
console.log(a % b);  // 1
console.log(a ** 2); // 100

a++;
console.log(a);      // 11
b--;
console.log(b);      // 2

Playwright Use Case: Calculating dynamic index for lists of elements or iterations.

docs.title: 🔹 Assignment Operators
docs.text:
Used to assign values to variables.

Operator Description = Assign += Add and assign -= Subtract and assign *= Multiply and assign /= Divide and assign %= Modulus and assign

docs.title: Examples – Assignment
docs.text:
let x;

// Assignment (=)
x = 10;
console.log(x); // 10

// Add and assign (+=)
x += 5;          // x = x + 5
console.log(x);  // 15

// Subtract and assign (-=)
x -= 3;          // x = x - 3
console.log(x);  // 12

// Multiply and assign (*=)
x *= 2;          // x = x * 2
console.log(x);  // 24

// Divide and assign (/=)
x /= 4;          // x = x / 4
console.log(x);  // 6

// Modulus and assign (%=)
x %= 5;          // x = x % 5
console.log(x);  // 1

// Exponentiate and assign (**=)
x **= 3;         // x = x ** 3
console.log(x);  // 1

// Bitwise AND and assign (&=)
x = 5;
x &= 3;          // x = x & 3
console.log(x);  // 1

// Bitwise OR and assign (|=)
x |= 2;          // x = x | 2
console.log(x);  // 3

// Bitwise XOR and assign (^=)
x ^= 1;          // x = x ^ 1
console.log(x);  // 2

// Left shift and assign (<<=)
x <<= 2;         // x = x << 2
console.log(x);  // 8

// Right shift and assign (>>=)
x >>= 1;         // x = x >> 1
console.log(x);  // 4

// Unsigned right shift and assign (>>>=)
x >>>= 1;        // x = x >>> 1
console.log(x);  // 2

docs.title: 🔹 Comparison Operators
docs.text:
Used to compare values, return true or false.

Operator Description == Equal (value only) === Strict equal (value + type) != Not equal !== Strict not equal > Greater than < Less than >= Greater or equal <= Less or equal

docs.title: Examples – Comparison
docs.text:
let a = 5;
let b = "5";

console.log(a == b);  // true (value equal)
console.log(a === b); // false (type mismatch)
console.log(a != b);  // false
console.log(a !== b); // true
console.log(a > 3);   // true
console.log(a <= 5);  // true

Playwright Use Case: Assertions for element counts, text lengths, or response values.

docs.title: 🔹 Logical Operators
docs.text:
Used to combine boolean expressions.

Operator Description && AND || OR ! NOT

docs.title: Examples – Logical
docs.text:
let isLoggedIn = true;
let hasAccess = false;

console.log(isLoggedIn && hasAccess); // false
console.log(isLoggedIn || hasAccess); // true
console.log(!isLoggedIn);             // false

Playwright Use Case: Conditional checks before clicking or filling fields.

docs.title: 🔹 Ternary Operator
docs.text: A shorthand for if...else statements.

docs.title: Syntax
docs.text: condition ? expression_if_true : expression_if_false;

docs.title: Examples – Ternary
docs.text:
let age = 18;
let message = age >= 18 ? "Adult" : "Minor";
console.log(message); // "Adult"

Playwright Use Case: Quick decision-making for optional actions, like filling optional forms.

docs.title: 🔹 Bitwise Operators
docs.text:
Operate on binary representations of numbers. Rarely used in Playwright but good to know.

Operator Description & AND | OR ^ XOR ~ NOT << Left shift >> Right shift >>> Zero-fill right shift

docs.title: Examples – Bitwise
docs.text:
let a = 5;  // 0101
let b = 3;  // 0011

console.log(a & b); // 1  (0001)
console.log(a | b); // 7  (0111)
console.log(a ^ b); // 6  (0110)
console.log(~a);    // -6

docs.title: ✅ Summary
docs.text:
• Arithmetic → +, -, *, /, %, ++, --, **
  • Assignment → =, +=, -=, *=, /=, %=
  • Comparison → ==, ===, !=, !==, >, <, >=, <=
  • Logical → &&, ||, !
  • Ternary → condition ? expr1 : expr2
  • Bitwise → &, |, ^, ~, <<, >>, >>>

These operators are essential for calculations, validations, and conditional logic in Playwright tests.

docs.title: JavaScript Functions: Regular vs Arrow
docs.text: We will explore the differences between regular functions and arrow functions using multiple examples.

docs.title: 1. Basic Syntax
docs.text:
// Regular function
function add(a, b) {
  return a + b;
}
console.log(add(2, 3)); // 5

// Arrow function
const addArrow = (a, b) => a + b;
console.log(addArrow(2, 3)); // 5

Key Difference: Arrow functions are shorter and automatically return a value if there is only one expression.

docs.title: 2. Single Parameter
docs.text:
// Regular function
function square(x) {
  return x * x;
}
console.log(square(5)); // 25

// Arrow function
const squareArrow = x => x * x;
console.log(squareArrow(5)); // 25
  • Parentheses () around a single parameter can be omitted in arrow functions.

docs.title: 3. Multiple Statements
docs.text:
// Regular function
function multiplyAndLog(a, b) {
  console.log("Multiplying", a, b);
  return a * b;
}
console.log(multiplyAndLog(2, 4)); // 8

// Arrow function
const multiplyAndLogArrow = (a, b) => {
  console.log("Multiplying", a, b);
  return a * b;
};
console.log(multiplyAndLogArrow(2, 4)); // 8
  • Curly braces {} are required for multiple statements, and return must be used explicitly.

docs.title: 4. this Behavior
docs.text:
// Regular function
function PersonRegular() {
  this.age = 0;

  setInterval(function() {
    this.age++; // `this` is undefined or global object
    console.log("Regular:", this.age);
  }, 1000);
}

// Arrow function
function PersonArrow() {
  this.age = 0;

  setInterval(() => {
    this.age++; // `this` refers to the PersonArrow instance
    console.log("Arrow:", this.age);
  }, 1000);
}

// Create instances
// new PersonRegular(); // won't work as expected
// new PersonArrow();   // `this` works correctly

Key Difference:

  • Regular functions have their own this.
  • Arrow functions inherit this from their surrounding context (lexical this).

docs.title: 5. Using with Array Methods
docs.text:
const numbers = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5];

// Regular function
const squaredRegular = numbers.map(function(n) {
  return n * n;
});
console.log(squaredRegular); // [1, 4, 9, 16, 25]

// Arrow function
const squaredArrow = numbers.map(n => n * n);
console.log(squaredArrow); // [1, 4, 9, 16, 25]
  • Arrow functions make array callbacks more concise.

docs.title: Summary of Differences
docs.text:
Feature Regular Function Arrow Function Syntax function(){} () => {} this binding Own this Lexical this (from surrounding) Arguments object Available Not available Can be used as constructor Yes No Ideal for General functions Short callbacks, functional programming

Arrow functions are mostly used for concise code and lexical this, while regular functions are still useful when you need arguments or constructor behavior.

docs.title: 1. What is a String?
docs.text:
A string in JavaScript is a sequence of characters used to represent text.\ Example:

let name = "Nitin";

docs.title: a) Single Quotes
docs.text: let city = 'Pune';

docs.title: b) Double Quotes
docs.text: let job = "Developer";

docs.title: c) Backticks (Template Literals)
docs.text:
Supports: - multiline strings\ - interpolation (${variable})

let user = "Nitin";
let msg = `Hello ${user}, welcome!`;

docs.title: 3. String Immutability
docs.text:
Strings in JavaScript cannot be changed after creation.

let s = "Hi";
s[0] = "h"; // ❌ does nothing
console.log(s); // "Hi"

To modify a string, create a new one:

s = "h" + s[1];
console.log(s); // "hi"

docs.title: == (loose equality)
docs.text:
Converts types before comparison.

"10" == 10   // true

docs.title: === (strict equality)
docs.text:
No type conversion.

"10" === 10  // false

docs.title: localeCompare()
docs.text:
Used for lexicographical comparison:

"apple".localeCompare("banana"); // -1

docs.title: 1. charAt(index)
docs.text:
Returns character at given index.

"Hello".charAt(1); // 'e'

docs.title: 2. at(index)
docs.text:
Supports negative index.

"Hello".at(-1); // 'o'

docs.title: 3. indexOf()
docs.text:
Finds first occurrence.

"javascript".indexOf("a"); // 1

Find After specific index

"javascript".indexOf("a", 2); //3

docs.title: 4. lastIndexOf()
docs.text:
Finds last occurrence.

"javascript".lastIndexOf("a"); // 3

docs.title: 5. includes()
docs.text:
Checks substring present or not.

"hello world".includes("world"); // true

docs.title: 6. startsWith()
docs.text: "JavaScript".startsWith("Java"); // true

docs.title: 7. endsWith()
docs.text: "JavaScript".endsWith("Script"); // true

docs.title: 8. slice(start, end)
docs.text:
Supports negative index.

"JavaScript".slice(0, 4); // 'Java'
"JavaScript".slice(-6);  // 'Script'

docs.title: 9. substring(start, end)
docs.text:
Negative values treated as 0.

"JavaScript".substring(4, 10); // "Script"

docs.title: 10. substr(start, length)
docs.text:
(Deprecated but asked in interviews)

"JavaScript".substr(4, 6); // "Script"

docs.title: 11. toUpperCase() / toLowerCase()
docs.text: "hello".toUpperCase(); // "HELLO"

docs.title: 12. trim()
docs.text: "   hi   ".trim(); // "hi"

docs.title: trimStart()
docs.text: "   hi".trimStart();

docs.title: trimEnd()
docs.text: "hi   ".trimEnd();

docs.title: 13. replace()
docs.text:
Replaces first match.

"hello world".replace("world","JS");

docs.title: replaceAll()
docs.text: "aa11aa".replaceAll("a","b");

docs.title: 14. split()
docs.text:
Converts string → array.

"apple,mango".split(",");

docs.title: 15. concat()
docs.text: "Hello".concat(" JavaScript");

docs.title: 16. match()
docs.text:
Regex matching.

"abc123".match(/[0-9]+/);

docs.title: 17. matchAll()
docs.text: [... "a1b2".matchAll(/[a-z]/g)];

docs.title: 18. padStart()
docs.text: "7".padStart(3,"0"); // "007"

docs.title: 19. padEnd()
docs.text: "7".padEnd(3,"0"); // "700"

docs.title: 20. repeat()
docs.text: "ha".repeat(3); // "hahaha"

docs.title: 21. localeCompare()
docs.text:
Lexicographic comparison.

"apple".localeCompare("banana"); // -1

docs.title: 22. valueOf()
docs.text:
Returns primitive string.

"hello".valueOf();

docs.title: 23. toString()
docs.text: (100).toString();

docs.title: 6. String Methods Table (Cheat Sheet)
docs.text: Method Description Example Output charAt() Returns char at index "Hi".charAt(1) i at() Supports negative index "Hi".at(-1) i indexOf() First occurrence "test".indexOf("t") 0 lastIndexOf() Last occurrence "test".lastIndexOf("t") 3 includes() True if substring exists "abc".includes("b") true startsWith() Checks starting "Java".startsWith("J") true endsWith() Checks ending "Java".endsWith("a") true slice() Extracts part "Java".slice(1,3) av substring() Similar to slice "Java".substring(1,3) av substr() start + length "JavaScript".substr(4,6) Script toUpperCase() Uppercase "hi".toUpperCase() HI toLowerCase() Lowercase "HI".toLowerCase() hi trim() Removes spaces " hi ".trim() hi replace() Replace first match "aabb".replace("a","c") cabb replaceAll() Replace all "aa".replaceAll("a","b") bb split() String → array "a,b".split(",") ["a","b"] concat() Joins strings "a".concat("b") ab match() Regex match "abc".match(/a/) ["a"] matchAll() All regex matches [... "a1a2".matchAll(/a/g)] [["a"], ["a"]] padStart() Left padding "5".padStart(3,"0") 005 padEnd() Right padding "5".padEnd(3,"0") 500 repeat() Repeat string "ha".repeat(3) hahaha localeCompare() Compare strings "a".localeCompare("b") -1

docs.title: Reverse string
docs.text: str.split("").reverse().join("");

docs.title: Check palindrome
docs.text: function isPalindrome(s){ return s === s.split("").reverse().join(""); }

docs.title: Count vowels
docs.text: (str.match(/[aeiou]/gi) || []).length;

docs.title: Character frequency
docs.text: for(let ch of str){ map[ch]=(map[ch]||0)+1; }

docs.title: First non-repeating character
docs.text:
for(let c of str){
  if(str.indexOf(c)===str.lastIndexOf(c)) return c;
}

docs.title: Find occurance of substring into main string
docs.text:
let newQuote='happy new year, new day, new vision'
let values=newQuote.indexOf("day")
let count=0

while(values!==-1){
    count++
    values =newQuote.indexOf("new",values+1)
}

console.log(count) //3

docs.title: 1. Scope
docs.text:
• var
    • Function-scoped
    • Available anywhere inside the function
  • let
    • Block-scoped
    • Available only inside the { } block where it is declared

docs.title: 2. Hoisting
docs.text:
• var
    • Hoisted and initialized with undefined
    • Can be accessed before declaration (but will be undefined)
  • let
    • Hoisted but not initialized
    • Cannot be accessed before declaration (Temporal Dead Zone)

docs.title: 3. Re-Declaration
docs.text:
• var
    • Allows re-declaration in the same scope
  • let
    • Does not allow re-declaration in the same scope

docs.title: 4. Global Object Property (Browser)
docs.text:
• var
    • Declared globally → becomes property of window object
  • let
    • Declared globally → does not attach to window

docs.title: 5. Recommended Usage
docs.text:
• var → Not preferred; avoid using in modern JS
  • let → Use for variables whose values will change
  • const → Prefer for fixed or constant values

docs.title: Comparison Table
docs.text:
Feature var let

Scope Function-scoped Block-scoped

Hoisting Yes (initialized with Yes (uninitialized, undefined) TDZ)

Re-declaration Allowed Not allowed

Global window property Yes No

Modern usage Not recommended Recommended

docs.title: JavaScript: var, let, const – Code Snippets with Explanations & Outputs
docs.text: This file contains detailed explanations for every example to help you understand real-world JavaScript behavior clearly.

docs.title: 1. var Scope (Function Scoped)
docs.text:
function testVarScope() {
  if (true) {
    var x = 10; // var is function-scoped
  }
  console.log("var x =", x); // Accessible here
}
testVarScope();

docs.title: Explanation
docs.text:
• var ignores block scope.
  • Even though x is declared inside the if block, it becomes available throughout the entire function.

docs.title: Output
docs.text: var x = 10

docs.title: 2. let Scope (Block Scoped)
docs.text:
function testLetScope() {
  if (true) {
    let y = 20; // let is block-scoped
    console.log("Inside block y =", y);
  }
  // console.log(y); // ReferenceError
}
testLetScope();

docs.title: Explanation
docs.text:
• let respects block scope ({}).
  • y is only available inside the if block.

docs.title: Output
docs.text: Inside block y = 20

docs.title: 3. Hoisting with var
docs.text:
console.log(a); // undefined
var a = 5;

docs.title: Explanation
docs.text:
• var is hoisted AND initialized with undefined during the memory creation phase.
  • This allows accessing it before declaration (but value is undefined).

docs.title: Output
docs.text: undefined

docs.title: 4. Hoisting with let (TDZ)
docs.text:
// console.log(b); // ReferenceError
let b = 10;

docs.title: Explanation
docs.text:
• let is hoisted but NOT initialized.
  • Accessing it before the declaration line results in a Temporal Dead Zone (TDZ) error.

docs.title: 5. Redeclaration Difference
docs.text:
var name = "Nitin";
var name = "Patil"; // ✔ allowed

let city = "Pune";
// let city = "Mumbai"; // ❌ SyntaxError
city = "Mumbai"; // ✔ allowed

docs.title: Explanation
docs.text:
• var allows redeclaration in the same scope.
  • let does not allow redeclaration but does allow reassignment.

docs.title: Output
docs.text:
var redeclared = Patil
let reassigned = Mumbai

docs.title: 6. Global Behavior (Browser Only)
docs.text:
var aVar = 100;
let aLet = 200;

console.log(window.aVar); // 100
console.log(window.aLet); // undefined

docs.title: Explanation
docs.text:
• Global var variables become properties of the global object (window).
  • Global let variables DO NOT attach to window.

docs.title: Output
docs.text:
100
undefined

docs.title: 7. Shadowing (Function Level)
docs.text:
var x = 1;

function demo() {
  var x = 2; // shadows global x
  console.log("Inside function x =", x);
}
demo();
console.log("Outside x =", x);

docs.title: Explanation
docs.text: • Re-declaring x inside the function creates a new variable, shadowing the global one.

docs.title: Output
docs.text:
Inside function x = 2
Outside x = 1

docs.title: 8. Shadowing with let (Block Level)
docs.text:
let num = 10;

{
  let num = 20; // block-level shadowing
  console.log("Inside block =", num);
}

console.log("Outside block =", num);

docs.title: Explanation
docs.text: • The inner let num shadows the outer variable only inside the block.

docs.title: Output
docs.text:
Inside block = 20
Outside block = 10

docs.title: 9. const with Mutable Objects
docs.text:
const user = { name: "Nitin", city: "Pune" };

user.city = "Mumbai"; // allowed
console.log(user);

// user = {}; // ❌ not allowed

docs.title: Explanation
docs.text:
• const prevents reassignment, not mutation.
  • You cannot assign a new object, but you can modify properties.

docs.title: Output
docs.text: { name: "Nitin", city: "Mumbai" }

docs.title: var Example
docs.text:
for (var i = 1; i <= 3; i++) {}
console.log("After loop, i =", i);

docs.title: Explanation
docs.text: • var leaks outside the loop because it is function scoped.

docs.title: Output
docs.text: After loop, i = 4

docs.title: let Example
docs.text:
for (let j = 1; j <= 3; j++) {}
// console.log(j); // ReferenceError

docs.title: Explanation
docs.text: • let is block-scoped → not available outside the loop.

docs.title: Problem with var
docs.text:
for (var i = 1; i <= 3; i++) {
  setTimeout(() => console.log("var i =", i), 100);
}

docs.title: Explanation
docs.text:
• var i is shared by all iterations.
  • When timeout executes, i is already 4.

docs.title: Output
docs.text:
var i = 4
var i = 4
var i = 4

docs.title: Correct with let
docs.text:
for (let i = 1; i <= 3; i++) {
  setTimeout(() => console.log("let i =", i), 100);
}

docs.title: Explanation
docs.text: • let creates a new i for each loop iteration.

docs.title: Output
docs.text:
let i = 1
let i = 2
let i = 3

docs.title: 12. Temporal Dead Zone (TDZ) Example
docs.text:
{
  // console.log(a); // ReferenceError
  let a = 50;
  console.log(a);
}

docs.title: Explanation
docs.text: • Accessing a before line of declaration causes TDZ error.

docs.title: Output
docs.text: 50

docs.title: 13. Final Interview-Level Example
docs.text:
var v = 1;
let l = 2;
const c = 3;

function show() {
  if (true) {
    var v = 10; // function scoped
    let l = 20; // block scoped
    const c2 = 30;
    console.log(v, l, c2);
  }
  console.log(v);
}
show();

docs.title: Explanation
docs.text:
• var v inside block overrides outer v inside function.
  • let l and const c2 remain block-scoped.

docs.title: Output
docs.text:
10 20 30
10

docs.title: 2. Variables (var, let, const) – Deep Dive
docs.text: JavaScript provides three ways to declare variables: var, let, and const. While all can store values, they differ in scope, re-declaration rules, hoisting behavior, and mutability.

docs.title: 🔹 var
docs.text:
• Function-scoped: A var declared inside a function is available throughout the function.
  • Ignores block scope: Declaring inside if, for, or {} does not limit its scope.
  • Hoisted: Moved to the top of the scope during compilation, initialized with undefined.
  • Allows re-declaration: You can declare the same variable again in the same scope (not recommended).

docs.title: Example – var inside block
docs.text:
if (true) {
  var x = "Hello";
}
console.log(x); // ✅ Accessible outside block

docs.title: Example – var inside function
docs.text:
function testVar() {
  if (true) {
    var inside = "Function scope";
  }
  console.log(inside); // ✅ Accessible anywhere inside the function
}
testVar();
console.log(typeof inside); // ❌ undefined globally

docs.title: Example – global var usage
docs.text:
var globalVar = "I am global";

function showGlobal() {
  console.log(globalVar); // ✅ Accessible inside function
}

showGlobal();
console.log(globalVar); // ✅ Accessible globally

docs.title: 🔹 let
docs.text:
• Block-scoped: Respects {} blocks like if, for, while.
  • No re-declaration: Cannot be declared twice in the same scope.
  • Hoisted but uninitialized: Exists in the Temporal Dead Zone (TDZ) until execution reaches its line.
  • Reassignment allowed.

docs.title: Example – let inside block
docs.text:
if (true) {
  let y = "Inside block";
  console.log(y); // ✅ Accessible here
}
// console.log(y); // ❌ ReferenceError outside block

docs.title: Example – let reassignment
docs.text:
let age = 25;
age = 30; // ✅ Reassignment allowed
// let age = 35; // ❌ Cannot redeclare in same scope

docs.title: 🔹 const
docs.text:
• Block-scoped (like let).
  • Must be initialized at declaration.
  • Cannot be reassigned, but if it’s an object/array, its contents can still be modified.

docs.title: Example – const
docs.text:
const country = "India";
// country = "USA"; // ❌ Error: Cannot reassign

const obj = { name: "Nitin" };
obj.name = "Patil"; // ✅ Allowed (property changed)
console.log(obj);   // { name: "Patil" }

docs.title: 🔹 Global vs Local with var
docs.text:
• Declaring a variable with var outside any function makes it global.
  • Reassigning it inside a function changes the global variable.
  • Re-declaring with var inside a function shadows the global variable instead of modifying it.

docs.title: Example – Reassignment updates global
docs.text:
var name = "Nitin";  // global

function updateGlobal() {
  name = "Patil";   // reassigns global
}
updateGlobal();
console.log(name);  // ✅ Patil (global updated)

docs.title: Example – Shadowing with var
docs.text:
var name = "Nitin";  // global

function shadowGlobal() {
  var name = "Local";  // new local variable
  console.log("Inside:", name); // Local
}
shadowGlobal();
console.log("Outside:", name);  // Nitin (global unchanged)

docs.title: ✅ Summary
docs.text:
• var → function-scoped, hoisted, allows re-declaration, unsafe in blocks.
  • let → block-scoped, safer, hoisted but uninitialized until line of code.
  • const → block-scoped, must be initialized, immutable binding but mutable objects.
  • Global vars can be reassigned inside functions.
  • Re-declaring with var inside a function shadows the global variable.

docs.title: Handling iFrames and Java-Based Dialogs/Popups in Playwright (JavaScript)
docs.text:
Modern web applications often use iFrames and dialog boxes/popups to display embedded content, alerts, confirmations, or system messages.

This document explains how to handle iFrames and Java-based dialogs/popups in Playwright with clear explanations and code examples.

docs.title: 1. Handling iFrames in Playwright
docs.text: An iFrame (Inline Frame) is an HTML document embedded inside another HTML document. Elements inside an iframe cannot be accessed directly from the main page.

docs.title: Types of iFrames
docs.text:
1. Single iFrame
  2. Multiple iFrames
  3. Nested iFrames
  4. Dynamic iFrames

docs.title: Sample HTML Structure (iFrame)
docs.text: <iframe id="loginFrame" src="login.html"></iframe>

docs.title: Accessing iFrame Using frameLocator() (Recommended)
docs.text:
const frame = page.frameLocator('#loginFrame');
await frame.locator('#username').fill('admin');
await frame.locator('#password').fill('password');
await frame.locator('#loginBtn').click();

docs.title: Why frameLocator()?
docs.text:
• Auto-waits for iframe
  • More reliable than frame()
  • Cleaner syntax

docs.title: Accessing iFrame Using frame()
docs.text:
const frame = page.frame({ name: 'loginFrame' });

await frame.fill('#username', 'admin');
await frame.fill('#password', 'password');
await frame.click('#loginBtn');

docs.title: Handling Nested iFrames
docs.text:
<iframe id="outerFrame">
  <iframe id="innerFrame"></iframe>
</iframe>

const innerFrame = page
  .frameLocator('#outerFrame')
  .frameLocator('#innerFrame');

await innerFrame.locator('#submit').click();

docs.title: Switching Back to Main Page
docs.text:
Playwright automatically switches context. Just use page.locator().

await page.locator('#logout').click();

docs.title: 2. Handling Java-Based Dialogs / Popups
docs.text:
Java-based or browser dialogs include: - Alert - Confirm - Prompt - BeforeUnload

These dialogs cannot be inspected using DOM locators.

docs.title: Handling Alert Popup
docs.text:
page.on('dialog', async dialog => {
  console.log(dialog.message());
  await dialog.accept();
});

await page.click('#alertButton');

docs.title: Handling Confirmation Popup (OK / Cancel)
docs.text:
page.on('dialog', async dialog => {
  if (dialog.type() === 'confirm') {
    await dialog.dismiss(); // Click Cancel
  }
});

await page.click('#confirmButton');

docs.title: Handling Prompt Popup (Enter Value)
docs.text:
page.on('dialog', async dialog => {
  await dialog.accept('Playwright User');
});

await page.click('#promptButton');

docs.title: Handling BeforeUnload Dialog
docs.text:
page.on('dialog', async dialog => {
  await dialog.accept();
});

docs.title: Important Dialog Methods
docs.text: Method Description dialog.accept() Click OK dialog.dismiss() Click Cancel dialog.message() Get dialog text dialog.type() alert / confirm / prompt

docs.title: Difference: Web Popup vs Java Dialog
docs.text: Web Popup Java Dialog DOM-based Browser-level Handled using locators Handled using dialog event Inspectable Not inspectable

docs.title: Handling Multiple Dialogs
docs.text:
page.on('dialog', async dialog => {
  console.log(`Dialog type: ${dialog.type()}`);
  await dialog.accept();
});

docs.title: Best Practices
docs.text:
• Use frameLocator() for iFrames
  • Always register dialog handler before clicking
  • Avoid hard waits
  • Validate dialog text when required

docs.title: Issue: Element not found inside iframe
docs.text: ✔ Ensure correct iframe locator ✔ Wait for iframe to load

docs.title: Issue: Dialog not handled
docs.text: ✔ Register page.on('dialog') before action

docs.title: Complete Example
docs.text:
import { test } from '@playwright/test';

test('iFrame and dialog handling', async ({ page }) => {

  await page.goto('https://example.com');

  // Handle iframe
  const frame = page.frameLocator('#loginFrame');
  await frame.locator('#username').fill('admin');

  // Handle alert dialog
  page.on('dialog', async dialog => {
    await dialog.accept();
  });

  await frame.locator('#submit').click();
});

docs.title: Conclusion
docs.text:
Playwright provides powerful and reliable APIs to handle: - iFrames using frameLocator() - Java-based dialogs using page.on('dialog')

These approaches are industry best practices for stable automation.

docs.title: Handling Auto-Suggestion Dropdown in Playwright (JavaScript)
docs.text:
Auto-suggestion dropdowns are widely used in modern web applications such as search boxes, country selectors, city inputs, and address fields.

This document explains how to handle auto-suggestion dropdowns in Playwright using JavaScript with a focus on the pressSequentially() method for realistic typing.

docs.title: Why pressSequentially()?
docs.text: pressSequentially() types characters one by one, just like a real user.

docs.title: Advantages
docs.text:
• Triggers all keyboard events (keydown, keyup, input)
  • Works reliably with JavaScript-based auto-suggestions
  • More stable than fill() for dynamic dropdowns
  • Mimics real user behavior

docs.title: Example
docs.text: await locator.pressSequentially('Ind');

docs.title: Requirement
docs.text:
• User types "Ind"
  • Auto-suggestion list appears
  • Select "India" from the dropdown

docs.title: Example Suggestions
docs.text:
• India
  • Indonesia
  • Indore

docs.title: Sample HTML Structure (Assumed)
docs.text:
<input id="country" />
<ul class="suggestions">
  <li>India</li>
  <li>Indonesia</li>
  <li>Indore</li>
</ul>

docs.title: Step-by-Step Automation Approach
docs.text:
1. Navigate to the page
  2. Locate the input field
  3. Click the input
  4. Type text using pressSequentially()
  5. Wait for suggestions to appear
  6. Read all suggestions
  7. Select the required option

docs.title: Playwright JavaScript Example
docs.text:
import { test, expect } from '@playwright/test';

test('Handle auto-suggestion dropdown using pressSequentially', async ({ page }) => {

  await page.goto('https://example.com');

  const countryInput = page.locator('#country');
  await countryInput.click();
  await countryInput.pressSequentially('Ind');

  const suggestions = page.locator('.suggestions li');
  await expect(suggestions).toHaveCountGreaterThan(0);

  const totalSuggestions = await suggestions.count();

  for (let i = 0; i < totalSuggestions; i++) {
    const suggestionText = await suggestions.nth(i).innerText();
    if (suggestionText.trim() === 'India') {
      await suggestions.nth(i).click();
      break;
    }
  }
});

docs.title: Keyboard-Based Selection
docs.text:
await countryInput.pressSequentially('Ind');
await page.waitForTimeout(500);
await countryInput.press('ArrowDown');
await countryInput.press('Enter');

docs.title: Best Practices
docs.text:
• Use stable locators (data-testid if available)
  • Avoid hard waits; use expect()
  • Prefer pressSequentially() for dynamic suggestions

docs.title: Conclusion
docs.text:
• Using pressSequentially() is the most reliable way to handle auto-suggestion dropdowns in Playwright with JavaScript.

  • In the previous lecture, we used the following step to enter characters into an edit dropbox:

  • await page.locator("[placeholder*='Country']").pressSequentially("ind"); This step may occasionally fail if the application server is slow due to heavy traffic. In such cases, you can introduce a delay and rewrite the step as:

  • await page.locator("[placeholder*='Country']").pressSequentially("ind", { delay: 150 }); Here, a delay of 150 milliseconds is introduced between each key press. That means it enters i → (delay 150 ms) → enters n → (delay 150 ms) → enters d

By doing this, you give the application enough time to respond with the relevant options.

docs.title: Calendar
docs.text:
const {test,expect} = require("@playwright/test");


test("Calendar validations",async({page})=>
{

    const monthNumber = "6";
    const date = "15";
    const year = "2027";
    const expectedList = [monthNumber,date,year];

    await page.goto("https://rahulshettyacademy.com/seleniumPractise/#/offers");
    await page.locator(".react-date-picker__inputGroup").click();
    await page.locator(".react-calendar__navigation__label").click();
    await page.locator(".react-calendar__navigation__label").click();
    await page.getByText(year).click();
    await page.locator(".react-calendar__year-view__months__month").nth(Number(monthNumber)-1).click();
    await page.locator("//abbr[text()='"+date+"']").click();

    const inputs =  page.locator('.react-date-picker__inputGroup__input')

    for(let i =0; i<expectedList.length;i++)
    {
        const value = await inputs.nth(i).inputValue();
        expect(value).toEqual(expectedList[i]);

    }

docs.title: Custom Fixture to Get Test Data
docs.text:
Plz refer below code,

1.https://github.com/automation-study-material/automation-testing/blob/main/PlayWrightAutomation/utils/test-base.js 2.https://github.com/automation-study-material/automation-testing/blob/main/PlayWrightAutomation/tests/ClientAppPO.spec.ts#L48C45-L48C61

docs.title: 📘 Handling Dropdowns in Playwright (JavaScript) — Complete Guide
docs.text:
Dropdowns are very common UI elements in web applications. Playwright provides multiple ways to handle different types of dropdowns depending on how they are implemented in HTML.

This guide covers ALL real-world dropdown scenarios with examples.

docs.title: 🧠 Types of Dropdowns in Web Applications
docs.text:
1. HTML <select> dropdown
  2. Custom dropdown (div / ul / li based)
  3. Autocomplete dropdown
  4. Multi-select dropdown
  5. Dynamic / async dropdown
  6. Shadow DOM dropdown
  7. Iframe dropdown

docs.title: Example HTML
docs.text:
<select id="country">
  <option value="IN">India</option>
  <option value="US">USA</option>
  <option value="UK">UK</option>
</select>

docs.title: Select by value
docs.text:
const dropdown=page.locator('#country');
dropdown.selectOption("IN");

await page.selectOption('#country', 'IN');

docs.title: Select by label
docs.text: await page.selectOption('#country', { label: 'India' });

docs.title: Select by index
docs.text: await page.selectOption('#country', { index: 1 });

docs.title: Select multiple values
docs.text: await page.selectOption('#country', ['IN', 'US']);

docs.title: Validate selected value
docs.text:
const value = await page.locator('#country').inputValue();
expect(value).toBe('IN');

docs.title: 2️⃣ Custom Dropdown (Div / UL / LI Based)
docs.text: selectOption() does NOT work here.

docs.title: Example HTML
docs.text:
<div class="dropdown">
  <div class="selected">Select City</div>
  <ul class="options">
    <li>Delhi</li>
    <li>Mumbai</li>
    <li>Pune</li>
  </ul>
</div>

docs.title: Handling custom dropdown
docs.text:
await page.click('.selected');
await page.click('li:has-text("Pune")');

docs.title: Stable locator approach
docs.text:
await page.locator('.dropdown').click();
await page.locator('.options li').filter({ hasText: 'Mumbai' }).click();

docs.title: 3️⃣ Autocomplete Dropdown
docs.text:
<input id="search" />
<ul class="suggestions">
  <li>Apple</li>
  <li>Apricot</li>
</ul>

docs.title: Handling autocomplete
docs.text:
await page.fill('#search', 'Ap');
await page.waitForSelector('.suggestions li');
await page.click('.suggestions li:has-text("Apple")');

docs.title: Keyboard selection
docs.text:
await page.fill('#search', 'Ap');
await page.keyboard.press('ArrowDown');
await page.keyboard.press('Enter');

docs.title: 4️⃣ Multi-Select Dropdown
docs.text:
<select id="skills" multiple>
  <option value="java">Java</option>
  <option value="js">JavaScript</option>
  <option value="py">Python</option>
</select>

await page.selectOption('#skills', ['java', 'js']);

const values = await page.locator('#skills').evaluate(
  el => Array.from(el.selectedOptions).map(o => o.value)
);
expect(values).toContain('java');

docs.title: 5️⃣ Dynamic / Async Dropdown
docs.text:
await page.click('#country');
await page.waitForSelector('li:has-text("India")');
await page.click('li:has-text("India")');

docs.title: 6️⃣ Dropdown Inside Shadow DOM
docs.text:
await page.locator('my-dropdown')
  .locator('li:has-text("Option 1")')
  .click();

docs.title: 7️⃣ Dropdown Inside Iframe
docs.text:
const frame = page.frameLocator('#payment-frame');
await frame.locator('#month').selectOption('March');

docs.title: 8️⃣ Keyboard Actions
docs.text:
await page.click('#country');
await page.keyboard.press('ArrowDown');
await page.keyboard.press('Enter');

docs.title: 9️⃣ Read All Options
docs.text:
const options = await page.locator('#country option').allTextContents();
console.log(options);

docs.title: 🔥 Common Mistakes
docs.text:
• Using selectOption() on custom dropdowns
  • Not waiting for dynamic options
  • Clicking hidden elements

docs.title: 🏆 Best Practices
docs.text:
• Prefer label over value
  • Use Playwright locators
  • Use frameLocator for iframes
  • Rely on auto-waiting

docs.title: 📌 Summary Table
docs.text:
Dropdown Type Recommended Method HTML select selectOption Custom dropdown Click + text Autocomplete Type + click Multi-select Array values Async Wait + click Shadow DOM Locator chaining Iframe frameLocator

Happy Testing 🚀

docs.title: Excel Handling
docs.text:
const ExcelJs = require('exceljs');
const { test, expect } = require('@playwright/test');

async function writeExcelTest(searchText, replaceText, change, filePath) {
  const workbook = new ExcelJs.Workbook();
  await workbook.xlsx.readFile(filePath);
  const worksheet = workbook.getWorksheet('Sheet1');
  const output = readExcel(worksheet, searchText); // not async

  const cell = worksheet.getCell(output.row, output.column + change.colChange);
  cell.value = replaceText;
  await workbook.xlsx.writeFile(filePath);
}

// This does no async work, so don't mark it async.
function readExcel(worksheet, searchText) {
  let output = { row: -1, column: -1 };
  worksheet.eachRow((row, rowNumber) => {
    row.eachCell((cell, colNumber) => {
      if (cell.value === searchText) {
        output = { row: rowNumber, column: colNumber };
      }
    });
  });
  return output;
}

//update Mango Price to 350. 
//writeExcelTest("Mango",350,{rowChange:0,colChange:2},"/Users/rahulshetty/downloads/excelTest.xlsx");

test('Upload download excel validation', async ({ page }) => {
  const textSearch = 'Mango';
  const updateValue = '350';

  await page.goto('https://rahulshettyacademy.com/upload-download-test/index.html');

  const download = page.waitForEvent('download');
  await page.getByRole('button', { name: 'Download' }).click();
  const dl = await download;
  const filePath = '/Users/rahulshetty/downloads/download.xlsx'; // or await dl.path()

  // ✅ Ensure the edit finishes before upload
  await writeExcelTest(textSearch, updateValue, { rowChange: 0, colChange: 2 }, filePath);

  await page.locator('#fileinput').setInputFiles(filePath);

  const desiredRow = await page.getByRole('row').filter({ has: page.getByText(textSearch) });
  await expect(desiredRow.locator('#cell-4-undefined')).toContainText(updateValue);
});

docs.title: General
docs.text:
page.locator(":''" -> new playwright method to point locatr. isVisible -> true/false waitFor() -> Methods help to to load element. Example. page.locator(" ").first().waitFor()

pressSequentially() -> type/fill wors in serach boc with sequentially Example "ind2" -> i later n later d -> fill directly past ind --> It helps to handle autosuggestion dropdown.

getByLabel getByPlaceholder getByRole

playwrigh debugg/trace/ui

filters - in locator use to filter from multiple WebElement

js-config file

default timeout is 30 sec, we can override in js configs with timeout and there is one more timeout for assertion,

timeout: 40*1000,
expect: {
  timeout: 40*1000,
}

docs.title: ✅ Short Answer
docs.text:
• inputValue() → returns the current value property of form elements
  • textContent() → returns the text inside an element

They are not interchangeable and are used for different types of elements.

docs.title: ❌ Incorrect understanding
docs.text: inputValue() returns what the user typed textContent() works for everything

docs.title: ✅ Correct understanding
docs.text: inputValue() → reads element.value (inputs, textareas, selects) textContent() → reads inner text of normal elements

docs.title: ✅ What it returns
docs.text:
inputValue() returns the current value of the input field — not how or who entered it.

That value can come from: - User typing - Playwright (fill(), type()) - HTML default value - JavaScript updates

Internally, Playwright reads:

element.value

docs.title: 1️⃣ User types manually
docs.text:
<input id="name">

User types Nitin

await page.locator('#name').inputValue();
// "Nitin"

docs.title: 2️⃣ Playwright fills the value
docs.text:
await page.locator('#name').fill('Patil');

await page.locator('#name').inputValue();
// "Patil"

docs.title: 3️⃣ Value set via HTML
docs.text:
<input id="city" value="Pune">

await page.locator('#city').inputValue();
// "Pune"

docs.title: 4️⃣ Value changed via JavaScript
docs.text:
await page.evaluate(() => {
  document.querySelector('#name').value = 'Mumbai';
});

await page.locator('#name').inputValue();
// "Mumbai"

docs.title: ❌ What inputValue() Does NOT Do
docs.text:
• Track keyboard events
  • Know who typed (user vs automation)
  • Read visible text
  • Read placeholders
  • Read inner text

docs.title: ✅ What it returns
docs.text:
textContent() returns the text inside an element, including hidden text.

It works for: - <div> - <span> - <p> - <label> - <button>

❌ It does NOT work for <input> or <textarea>

Internally, Playwright reads:

element.textContent

docs.title: 1️⃣ Reading visible text
docs.text:
<div id="msg">Welcome Nitin</div>

await page.locator('#msg').textContent();
// "Welcome Nitin"

docs.title: 2️⃣ Hidden text is included
docs.text:
<div id="status">
  Success
  <span style="display:none">Hidden</span>
</div>

await page.locator('#status').textContent();
// "SuccessHidden"

docs.title: 3️⃣ ❌ Common mistake
docs.text:
await page.locator('#name').textContent(); // ❌ WRONG

Reason:

<input> elements do not have inner text — only a value.

docs.title: 🆚 inputValue() vs textContent()
docs.text: Feature inputValue() textContent() Used for Input elements Normal elements Reads element.value element.textContent Works on <input> ✅ Yes ❌ No Includes hidden text N/A ✅ Yes Tracks typing ❌ No ❌ No

docs.title: 🆚 inputValue() vs getAttribute('value')
docs.text:
<input id="email" value="initial@mail.com">

User types changed@mail.com

Method Returned Value inputValue() changed@mail.com getAttribute('value') initial@mail.com

docs.title: ✅ Best Practice in Playwright (Recommended)
docs.text:
await expect(page.locator('#email')).toHaveValue('changed@mail.com');
await expect(page.locator('#msg')).toHaveText('Welcome Nitin');

docs.title: 🧠 Easy Rule to Remember
docs.text: User enters data → inputValue() User sees text → textContent()

docs.title: 📌 Final Answer
docs.text: inputValue() returns the current value property of form fields. textContent() returns the text inside normal DOM elements.

docs.title: 📘 Iterating Data from JSON in JavaScript (Complete Guide)
docs.text: This document explains how to load, parse, and iterate JSON data in JavaScript, from simple JSON to complex nested JSON, including Playwright usage.

docs.title: Example: testdata/login.json
docs.text:
{
  "username": "admin",
  "password": "admin123"
}

docs.title: Load JSON
docs.text:
const loginData = require('../testdata/login.json');
console.log(loginData.username);

docs.title: 📌 2. Iterating Simple JSON Object
docs.text:
const user = {
  name: "Nitin",
  role: "DevOps",
  experience: 3
};

for (const key in user) {
  console.log(key + " : " + user[key]);
}

docs.title: 📌 3. Iterating JSON Array
docs.text:
const data = { skills: ["Java", "Docker", "Kubernetes"] };

data.skills.forEach(skill => {
  console.log(skill);
});

docs.title: 📌 4. Array of Objects (Common)
docs.text:
{
  "users": [
    { "id": 1, "name": "Amit", "role": "QA" },
    { "id": 2, "name": "Nitin", "role": "DevOps" }
  ]
}

usersData.users.forEach(user => {
  console.log(user.name + " - " + user.role);
});

docs.title: 📌 5. Nested JSON Iteration
docs.text:
orderData.order.items.forEach(item => {
  console.log(item.product);
});

docs.title: 📌 6. Safe Iteration
docs.text:
orderData?.order?.items?.forEach(item => {
  console.log(item.product);
});

docs.title: 📌 7. Deep Copy Before Iteration
docs.text: const data = JSON.parse(JSON.stringify(require('./users.json')));

docs.title: 📌 8. Playwright Example
docs.text:
usersData.users.forEach(user => {
  test(`Login test for ${user.name}`, async ({ page }) => {
    await page.fill('#username', user.name);
  });
});

docs.title: 🔥 Best Practices
docs.text:
• Keep JSON in testdata folder
  • Avoid mutating shared JSON
  • Use deep clone when needed
  • Prefer optional chaining

📘 End of Document

docs.title: Playwright Locators -- Complete Guide (JavaScript)
docs.text: This guide covers all locator strategies in Playwright (JavaScript) and explains when and why to use each type.

docs.title: 🔹 Example Base HTML
docs.text:
<input type="text" id="email" class="form-control" placeholder="Enter email" />

<button id="submitBtn" class="btn btn-primary" type="submit">Submit</button>

<span class="text">Title</span>

<a href="/home">Home</a>

docs.title: 🔹 Locator Types (With Context + HTML + JS Example)
1️⃣ Locate by ID
docs.text: IDs are unique within a page, making them the most reliable and fastest selectors.

docs.title: 🔸 HTML:
docs.text:
<input id="email" />
<button id="submitBtn">Submit</button>

docs.title: 🔸 Playwright:
docs.text:
page.locator("#email");
page.locator("#submitBtn").click();

docs.title: 2️⃣ Locate by Class
docs.text: Class selectors are useful when elements share styling or behavior.

docs.title: 🔸 HTML:
docs.text:
<input class="form-control" />
<button class="btn btn-primary">Save</button>

docs.title: 🔸 Playwright:
docs.text:
page.locator(".form-control");
page.locator(".btn.btn-primary").click();

docs.title: 3️⃣ Locate by Tag Name
docs.text: Used when selecting elements by their tag type.

docs.title: 🔸 HTML:
docs.text:
<button>Submit</button>
<input type="text" />

docs.title: 🔸 Playwright:
docs.text:
page.locator("button");
page.locator("input");

docs.title: 4️⃣ Locate by Text Content
docs.text: Useful for selecting elements based on visible text.

docs.title: 🔸 HTML:
docs.text:
<button>Submit</button>
<a>Home</a>

docs.title: 🔸 Playwright:
docs.text:
page.getByText("Submit").click();
page.getByText("Home");

docs.title: 5️⃣ Locate by ARIA Role (Recommended)
docs.text: This is Playwright's most powerful and stable locator type.

docs.title: 🔸 HTML:
docs.text:
<button type="submit">Submit</button>
<a href="/home">Home</a>

docs.title: 🔸 Playwright:
docs.text:
page.getByRole("button", { name: "Submit" }).click();
page.getByRole("link", { name: "Home" });

docs.title: 6️⃣ Locate by Placeholder
docs.text: Great for selecting input elements using placeholder text.

docs.title: 🔸 HTML:
docs.text: <input placeholder="Enter email" />

docs.title: 🔸 Playwright:
docs.text: page.getByPlaceholder("Enter email").fill("abc@test.com");

docs.title: 7️⃣ Locate by Label
docs.text: Automatically links <label> to its corresponding <input>.

docs.title: 🔸 HTML: (Applicable)
docs.text:
• It will work onlu when there is association with label field see below example.
  • here you can see email is linked between label and input id.
  • In some cases input field is wrapped in labes.
<label for="email">Email</label>
<input id="email" />

docs.title: 🔸 HTML: (NOT Applicable)
docs.text:
• It will not work when there is NO association with label and input field see below example.
div class="form-group">
    <label>Name</label>
       <input class="form-control ng-untouched ng-pristine ng-invalid" minlength="2" name="name" required="" type="text">
</div>

docs.title: 🔸 Playwright:
docs.text: page.getByLabel("Email").fill("test@domain.com");

docs.title: 8️⃣ Locate by Alt Text
docs.text: Useful for images.

docs.title: 🔸 HTML:
docs.text: <img src="logo.png" alt="Company Logo">

docs.title: 🔸 Playwright:
docs.text: page.getByAltText("Company Logo");

docs.title: 9️⃣ Locate by Title Attribute
docs.text: Handy when elements do not have visible text.

docs.title: 🔸 HTML:
docs.text: <button title="Click to submit">Submit</button>

docs.title: 🔸 Playwright:
docs.text: page.getByTitle("Click to submit").click();

docs.title: 🔸 HTML:
docs.text:
<input type="text" />
<button type="submit">Save</button>
<a href="/home">Home</a>

docs.title: 🔸 Playwright:
docs.text:
page.locator("input[type='text']");
page.locator("button[type='submit']");
page.locator("a[href='/home']");

docs.title: 🔸 HTML:
docs.text:
<input id="email" />
<button>Submit</button>

docs.title: 🔸 Playwright:
docs.text:
page.locator("//input[@id='email']");
page.locator("//button[text()='Submit']");

docs.title: 🔸 HTML:
docs.text:
<ul>
  <li class="item">Apple</li>
  <li class="item">Banana</li>
  <li class="item">Cherry</li>
</ul>

docs.title: 🔸 Playwright:
docs.text:
const items = page.locator(".item");
const count = await items.count();

await items.nth(0).innerText();
await items.nth(1).innerText();
await items.nth(2).innerText();

for (let i = 0; i < count; i++) {
  console.log(await items.nth(i).innerText());
}

const banana = page.locator(".item").filter({ hasText: "Banana" });

page.locator(".item").first();
page.locator(".item").last();

docs.title: 🔸 Snap code:
docs.text:
import { test, expect } from '@playwright/test';

test('Playwright Special locators', async ({ page }) => {

    await page.goto("https://rahulshettyacademy.com/angularpractice/");
    await page.getByLabel("Check me out if you Love IceCreams!").click();
    await page.getByLabel("Employed").check();
    await page.getByLabel("Gender").selectOption("Female");
    await page.getByPlaceholder("Password").fill("abc123");
    await page.getByRole("button", {name: 'Submit'}).click();
    await page.getByText("Success! The Form has been submitted successfully!.").isVisible();
    await page.getByRole("link",{name : "Shop"}).click();
    await page.locator("app-card").filter({hasText: 'Nokia Edge'}).getByRole("button").click();

    //locator(css)

});

const { test, expect } = require('@playwright/test');




test('@Webst Client App login', async ({ page }) => {
   //js file- Login js, DashboardPage
   const email = "anshika@gmail.com";
   const productName = 'ZARA COAT 3';
   const products = page.locator(".card-body");
   await page.goto("https://rahulshettyacademy.com/client");
   await page.getByPlaceholder("email@example.com").fill(email);
   await page.getByPlaceholder("enter your passsword").fill("Iamking@000");
   await page.getByRole('button',{name:"Login"}).click();
   await page.waitForLoadState('networkidle');
   await page.locator(".card-body b").first().waitFor();

   await page.locator(".card-body").filter({hasText:"ZARA COAT 3"})
   .getByRole("button",{name:"Add to Cart"}).click();

   await page.getByRole("listitem").getByRole('button',{name:"Cart"}).click();

   //await page.pause();
   await page.locator("div li").first().waitFor();
   await expect(page.getByText("ZARA COAT 3")).toBeVisible();

   await page.getByRole("button",{name :"Checkout"}).click();

   await page.getByPlaceholder("Select Country").pressSequentially("ind");

   await page.getByRole("button",{name :"India"}).nth(1).click();
   await page.getByText("PLACE ORDER").click();

   await expect(page.getByText("Thankyou for the order.")).toBeVisible();
})

docs.title: 🔹 Summary
docs.text:
• Prefer semantic locators → getByRole, getByLabel, getByPlaceholder
  • Use CSS/XPath only when needed
  • Use .nth(), .first(), .last(), .filter() for multi-elements

docs.title: Methods in Playwright
docs.text:
• type - entering values
  • click - click
  • textContent() - get text from locator

  • expect to containText aseertion js await expect(locator).toContainText("expected string");

  • if we use lovator which matches to multiple element in dom and we tring to get string we get below error, error STRINCT MODE VIOLATION

  • How we can travel from parent to child in playwright with css await page.locator(".card-body a").nth(0).textContent - It return 1st element/index bases OR await page.locator(".card-body a").first().textContent - It return 1st element OR await page.locator(".card-body a").last().textContent - It return last element

  • Scenario Want to store all product text in list etc.

    • locator.alltextContents(); js console.log(await cardTitles.nth(1).textContent()); //textContent() by default have wait mechanism const allTitle=await page.locator(".card-body a").alltextContents(); // It didint not have and It will fail if we run only this line
    • To avoid failure in above step we have to add wait till all api network call done. js await page.goto("https://rahulshettyacademy.com/client"); await page.locator("#userEmail").fill("anshika@gmail.com"); await page.locator("#userPassword").fill("Iamking@000"); await page.locator("[value='Login']").click(); await page.waitForLoadState('networkidle'); // Sometimes not woks fine- Also mention in playwright official document. so we use below case const titles=await page.locator(".card-body b").allTextContents(); concole.log(titles);
    • waitFor() we can use js await page.locator(".card-body b").first().waitFor(); - Waiting for first await page.locator(".card-body b").last().waitFor(); - waiting for last

docs.title: 📘 Playwright { page } vs { browser } — How Browser Selection Works
docs.text:
This guide explains:

What { page } means

What { browser } means

How Playwright decides which browser to use

How configuration affects test execution

## ✅ 1. Using { page } (Most Common)
test('@Web UI Controls', async ({ page }) => {
  await page.goto("https://rahulshettyacademy.com/loginpagePractise/");
});

✔ How it works

Playwright automatically creates:

a browser (from config)

a browser context

a page

You don’t manage the browser manually.

✔ Default Browser

If you do NOT configure anything, Playwright uses:

Chromium (default)

docs.title: 📌 2. Using { browser } (Manual Control)
docs.text:
test('@Web Browser Context-Validating Error login', async ({ browser }) => {
  const context = await browser.newContext();
  const page = await context.newPage();
});

✔ How it works

Here you are responsible for:

creating the context

creating the page

applying custom settings

✔ When to use

Multi-user scenarios

Custom viewport, geolocation, permissions

Reusing login state

Recording video per test

Multi-tab testing

docs.title: 🆚 3. Difference Between { page } and { browser }
docs.text:
Feature { page } { browser } Browser comes from config ✅ Yes ❌ No (you create manually) Context is auto-created ✅ ❌ Best for Simple UI tests Advanced/customized tests Multi-browser testing Automatic via config Must handle manually Custom context options Limited Full control Simpler to write ✔✔✔ ✔ 🚀 4. Which Browser Does { page } Use? ✔ It uses whatever is defined in your playwright.config.js.

Example default config:

// playwright.config.js
module.exports = {
  projects: [
    {
      name: 'chromium',
      use: { browserName: 'chromium' }
    }
  ]
};

👉 Result

All { page } tests run in Chromium.

📌 5. Running Tests in Multiple Browsers

projects: [
  { name: 'chromium', use: { browserName: 'chromium' } },
  { name: 'firefox', use: { browserName: 'firefox' } },
  { name: 'webkit', use: { browserName: 'webkit' } }
]

Running:

npx playwright test

👉 { page } tests will run in all three browsers automatically. 🔧 6. Browser Selection Summary ✔ { page }

Browser is selected from config

Usually Chromium unless changed

Automatic, beginner-friendly

✔ { browser }

You control context/page creation

Use only when needed

Allows full customization

⭐ Final Summary

{ page } uses the default browser defined in Playwright config. If no project is configured, it uses Chromium. { browser } gives you manual control for custom scenarios.

docs.title: Locator Assertions
docs.text: Assertion Description Syntax Example toBeVisible() Element should be visible await expect(locator).toBeVisible() await expect(page.getByText("Login")).toBeVisible(); toBeHidden() Element exists but not visible await expect(locator).toBeHidden() await expect(page.locator('#loader')).toBeHidden(); toBeEnabled() Element is enabled await expect(locator).toBeEnabled() await expect(page.locator('#submit')).toBeEnabled(); toBeDisabled() Element is disabled await expect(locator).toBeDisabled() await expect(page.locator('#submit')).toBeDisabled(); toBeEditable() Input is editable await expect(locator).toBeEditable() await expect(page.locator('#name')).toBeEditable(); toBeChecked() Checkbox is checked await expect(locator).toBeChecked() await expect(page.locator('#terms')).toBeChecked(); not.toBeChecked() Checkbox not checked await expect(locator).not.toBeChecked() await expect(page.locator('#subscribe')).not.toBeChecked(); toHaveAttribute() Matches attribute value await expect(locator).toHaveAttribute(name, value) await expect(page.locator('#loginBtn')).toHaveAttribute('type','submit'); toHaveClass() Matches CSS class await expect(locator).toHaveClass(value) await expect(page.locator('.item')).toHaveClass(/active/); toHaveId() Matches element id await expect(locator).toHaveId(value) await expect(page.locator('#username')).toHaveId('username'); toHaveText() Exact/regex text match await expect(locator).toHaveText(value) await expect(page.locator('.msg')).toHaveText(/Success/); toContainText() Partial text match await expect(locator).toContainText(value) await expect(page.locator('.label')).toContainText("Hello"); toHaveValue() Input value match await expect(locator).toHaveValue(value) await expect(page.locator('#email')).toHaveValue("test@gmail.com"); toHaveValues() Multi-select values await expect(locator).toHaveValues(array) await expect(page.locator('#cities')).toHaveValues(['NY', 'LA']); toHaveCount() Number of elements await expect(locator).toHaveCount(number) await expect(page.locator('.cart-item')).toHaveCount(3); toBeEmpty() No content await expect(locator).toBeEmpty() await expect(page.locator('#output')).toBeEmpty(); toBeInViewport() Element inside viewport await expect(locator).toBeInViewport() await expect(page.locator('#banner')).toBeInViewport();

docs.title: Page Assertions
docs.text: Assertion Description Syntax Example toHaveURL() Matches URL await expect(page).toHaveURL(value) await expect(page).toHaveURL(/dashboard/); toHaveTitle() Matches page title await expect(page).toHaveTitle(value) await expect(page).toHaveTitle("Login Page");

docs.title: API Assertions
docs.text: Assertion Description Syntax Example toBeOK() Status is 2xx await expect(response).toBeOK() const res = await request.get(url); await expect(res).toBeOK(); status() code Exact HTTP code expect(response.status()).toBe(value) expect(res.status()).toBe(201); json body check Validate JSON expect(await res.json()).toEqual(obj) const body = await res.json(); expect(body.success).toBe(true);

docs.title: Soft Assertions
docs.text: Feature Syntax Example Soft assertion expect.soft(locator).assertion() expect.soft(page.locator('#msg')).toContainText('Success'); console.log("Test continues");

docs.title: Negated Assertions
docs.text: Negated Syntax Example expect(locator).not.toBeVisible() await expect(page.locator('#error')).not.toBeVisible(); expect(locator).not.toHaveText(value) await expect(page.locator('#msg')).not.toHaveText('Error'); expect(page).not.toHaveURL(value) await expect(page).not.toHaveURL(/login/);

docs.title: Assertions With Timeout
docs.text: Syntax Example await expect(locator).assertion({ timeout: ms }) await expect(page.locator('#status')).toHaveText("Done", { timeout: 8000 });

docs.title: 📘 Handling Radio Buttons in Playwright (JavaScript) — Complete Guide
docs.text:
Radio buttons allow users to select ONLY ONE option from a group. Playwright provides clean and reliable APIs to handle radio buttons in both simple and complex real-world scenarios.

This guide covers basic to advanced radio button handling, including validations and edge cases.

docs.title: 🧠 What is a Radio Button?
docs.text:
• Represented by <input type="radio">
  • Grouped using the same name attribute
  • Only one option can be selected at a time

docs.title: Example HTML
docs.text:
<input type="radio" name="gender" value="male" id="male">
<label for="male">Male</label>

<input type="radio" name="gender" value="female" id="female">
<label for="female">Female</label>

docs.title: ✔ Select radio button by ID
docs.text: await page.check('#male');

docs.title: ✔ Select by value
docs.text: await page.locator('input[name="gender"][value="female"]').check();

docs.title: ✔ Validate selected radio button
docs.text:
await expect(page.locator('#male')).toBeChecked();
await expect(page.locator('#female')).not.toBeChecked();

docs.title: 2️⃣ Selecting Radio Button Using Label Text
docs.text: await page.getByLabel('Male').check();

docs.title: 3️⃣ Radio Button Group Handling
docs.text:
const gender = 'female';

await page
  .locator('input[name="gender"]')
  .filter({ has: page.locator(`[value="${gender}"]`) })
  .check();

docs.title: 4️⃣ Disabled Radio Button
docs.text:
<input type="radio" name="status" value="active" disabled>

await expect(page.locator('input[value="active"]')).toBeDisabled();

docs.title: 5️⃣ Default Selected Radio Button
docs.text:
<input type="radio" name="payment" value="upi" checked>

await expect(page.locator('input[value="upi"]')).toBeChecked();

docs.title: 6️⃣ Custom Styled Radio Buttons
docs.text: await page.locator('.radio').filter({ hasText: 'Gold' }).click();

docs.title: 7️⃣ Dynamically Loaded Radio Buttons
docs.text:
await page.waitForSelector('input[name="plan"]');
await page.locator('input[value="premium"]').check();

docs.title: 8️⃣ Radio Button Inside Iframe
docs.text:
const frame = page.frameLocator('#settings-frame');
await frame.getByLabel('Dark Mode').check();

docs.title: 9️⃣ Keyboard Interaction
docs.text:
await page.focus('#male');
await page.keyboard.press('ArrowRight');

docs.title: 🚀 Complex Real-World Scenario
docs.text:
test('Complex radio button flow', async ({ page }) => {
  await page.goto('https://example.com/register');

  await page.waitForSelector('input[name="role"]');
  await expect(page.locator('input[value="admin"]')).toBeDisabled();

  await page.locator('input[value="user"]').check();
  await expect(page.locator('#subscription')).toBeVisible();

  await page.locator('input[value="pro"]').check();
  await expect(page.locator('input[value="pro"]')).toBeChecked();
  await expect(page.locator('input[value="pro"]').isChecked).toBeTruthy();
});

Happy Testing 🚀

docs.title: 1. Handle auto suggestion dropdown and E2E flow
docs.text:
const { test, expect } = require('@playwright/test');
test('@Webst Client App login', async ({ page }) => {
   //js file- Login js, DashboardPage
   const email = "anshika@gmail.com";
   const productName = 'ZARA COAT 3';
   const products = page.locator(".card-body");
   await page.goto("https://rahulshettyacademy.com/client");
   await page.locator("#userEmail").fill(email);
   await page.locator("#userPassword").fill("Iamking@000");
   await page.locator("[value='Login']").click();
   await page.waitForLoadState('networkidle');
   await page.locator(".card-body b").first().waitFor();
   const titles = await page.locator(".card-body b").allTextContents();
   console.log(titles); 
   const count = await products.count();
   for (let i = 0; i < count; ++i) {
      if (await products.nth(i).locator("b").textContent() === productName) {
         //add to cart
         await products.nth(i).locator("text= Add To Cart").click();
         break;
      }
   }

   await page.locator("[routerlink*='cart']").click();
   //await page.pause();

   await page.locator("div li").first().waitFor();
   const bool = await page.locator("h3:has-text('ZARA COAT 3')").isVisible();
   expect(bool).toBeTruthy();
   await page.locator("text=Checkout").click();

  await page.getByPlaceholder('Select Country').pressSequentially("ind", { delay: 150 }) 
   const dropdown = page.locator(".ta-results");
   await dropdown.waitFor();
   const optionsCount = await dropdown.locator("button").count();
   for (let i = 0; i < optionsCount; ++i) {
      const text = await dropdown.locator("button").nth(i).textContent();
      if (text === " India") {
         await dropdown.locator("button").nth(i).click();
         break;
      }
   }

   expect(page.locator(".user__name [type='text']").first()).toHaveText(email);
   await page.locator(".action__submit").click();
   await expect(page.locator(".hero-primary")).toHaveText(" Thankyou for the order. ");
   const orderId = await page.locator(".em-spacer-1 .ng-star-inserted").textContent();
   console.log(orderId);

   await page.locator("button[routerlink*='myorders']").click();
   await page.locator("tbody").waitFor();
   const rows = await page.locator("tbody tr");


   for (let i = 0; i < await rows.count(); ++i) {
      const rowOrderId = await rows.nth(i).locator("th").textContent();
      if (orderId.includes(rowOrderId)) {
         await rows.nth(i).locator("button").first().click();
         break;
      }
   }
   const orderIdDetails = await page.locator(".col-text").textContent();
   expect(orderId.includes(orderIdDetails)).toBeTruthy(); 
});

### 2. Handle web Table for order history ```js const { test, expect } = require('@playwright/test');
