test('@Webst Client App login', async ({ page }) => { //js file- Login js, DashboardPage const email = "anshika@gmail.com"; const productName = 'ZARA COAT 3'; const products = page.locator(".card-body"); await page.goto("https://rahulshettyacademy.com/client"); await page.locator("#userEmail").fill(email); await page.locator("#userPassword").fill("Iamking@000"); await page.locator("[value='Login']").click(); await page.waitForLoadState('networkidle'); await page.locator(".card-body b").first().waitFor(); const titles = await page.locator(".card-body b").allTextContents(); console.log(titles); const count = await products.count(); for (let i = 0; i < count; ++i) { if (await products.nth(i).locator("b").textContent() === productName) { //add to cart await products.nth(i).locator("text= Add To Cart").click(); break; } }

await page.locator("[routerlink*='cart']").click(); //await page.pause();

await page.locator("div li").first().waitFor(); const bool = await page.locator("h3:has-text('ZARA COAT 3')").isVisible(); expect(bool).toBeTruthy(); await page.locator("text=Checkout").click();

await page.locator("[placeholder*='Country']").pressSequentially("ind", { delay: 150 }); const dropdown = page.locator(".ta-results"); await dropdown.waitFor(); const optionsCount = await dropdown.locator("button").count(); for (let i = 0; i < optionsCount; ++i) { const text = await dropdown.locator("button").nth(i).textContent(); if (text === " India") { await dropdown.locator("button").nth(i).click(); break; } }

expect(page.locator(".user__name [type='text']").first()).toHaveText(email); await page.locator(".action__submit").click(); await expect(page.locator(".hero-primary")).toHaveText(" Thankyou for the order. "); const orderId = await page.locator(".em-spacer-1 .ng-star-inserted").textContent(); console.log(orderId);

await page.locator("button[routerlink*='myorders']").click(); await page.locator("tbody").waitFor(); const rows = await page.locator("tbody tr");

for (let i = 0; i < await rows.count(); ++i) { const rowOrderId = await rows.nth(i).locator("th").textContent(); if (orderId.includes(rowOrderId)) { await rows.nth(i).locator("button").first().click(); break; } } const orderIdDetails = await page.locator(".col-text").textContent(); expect(orderId.includes(orderIdDetails)).toBeTruthy();

}); ```

docs.title: 📘 Playwright – All Ways to Enter or Send Text (Complete Guide)
docs.text: This document explains all Playwright methods used to type, insert, or send data into input fields, including their behavior, usage, and differences.

docs.title: 🔥 Quick Summary Table
docs.text: Method Clears existing text? Types like human? Triggers keyboard events? Speed Best For fill() ✔ Yes ❌ No Partial Fast Standard form input type() ❌ No (appends) ✔ Yes ✔ Full Slow/realistic Autocomplete, key events keyboard.type() ❌ No ✔ Yes ✔ Full Slow/realistic When element already focused keyboard.press() ❌ No Key only ✔ Full Fast Keyboards shortcuts, Enter/Tab keyboard.insertText() ❌ No ❌ No ❌ No Fastest Bypassing JS events evaluate() ✔ Yes ❌ No ❌ No Fast When normal methods fail

docs.title: 1️⃣ fill() – Fast, Clears Field, No Keystrokes
docs.text:
✔ Important Points - Clears existing text automatically - Inserts value instantly (not typed) - Does NOT trigger keydown/keyup for each character - Only final input/change events fire - Fastest common method

✔ Example

  await page.locator("#username").fill("john");

✔ When to Use - Standard form filling - When old text must be removed - When speed matters

docs.title: 2️⃣ type() – Human-Like Typing, Doesn’t Clear
docs.text:
✔ Important Points - ❗ Does NOT clear existing text → it appends - Types characters one by one - Triggers keydown → keypress → keyup for every character - Works like a human typing - Supports typing delays

✔ Example

  await page.locator("#username").type("john");

If field has old: ➡️ Result → oldjohn

✔ With delay

await page.locator("#username").type("john", { delay: 150 });

✔ When to Use - Autocomplete searches - Events tied to keystrokes - When simulating a real user

docs.title: 3️⃣ keyboard.type() – Type Into Focused Element
docs.text:
✔ Important Points - Same as type(), but uses keyboard, not locator - Requires clicking or focusing element first - Triggers full key events - Does not clear text

✔ Example

await page.click("#username");
await page.keyboard.type("john doe");

✔ When to Use - When interacting with dynamic editors (CodeMirror, Monaco) - When locator typing fails

docs.title: 4️⃣ keyboard.press() – Single Key Press
docs.text:
✔ Important Points - Sends one key press, not text - Useful for shortcuts: Enter, Backspace, Tab, ArrowUp - Triggers full keydown/keyup events - Does not clear text

✔ Example

await page.locator("#username").press("Control+A");
await page.locator("#username").press("Backspace");
await page.locator("#username").press("Enter");

✔ When to Use - Submitting forms (Enter) - Moving focus (Tab) - Hotkeys & shortcuts

docs.title: 5️⃣ keyboard.insertText() – Insert Text Without Keystrokes
docs.text:
✔ Important Points - Does NOT trigger any key events - Does not simulate typing - Does not clear text - Inserts text directly into DOM - Fastest method when keystrokes not needed

✔ Example

await page.click("#username");
await page.keyboard.insertText("john");

✔ When to Use - Avoiding event listeners - Speed/performance testing - Inputs that block simulated typing

docs.title: 6️⃣ evaluate() – Set Value Using JavaScript
docs.text:
✔ Important Points - Uses page JS context to set .value - Does not fire key events - Does not simulate typing - Completely bypasses frontend validations - Clears existing text only if you set empty string

✔ Example

await page.locator("#username").evaluate(el => el.value = 'john');

✔ When to Use - When UI blocks typing/filling - React/Angular controlled inputs - Special custom editors

docs.title: Clearing Behavior
docs.text:
• ✔ fill() clears text
  • ✔ evaluate() can clear if set to ""
  • ❌ Others do not clear

docs.title: Typing Simulation
docs.text: Only these behave like real typing: - type() - keyboard.type()

docs.title: Trigger Events
docs.text:
• type() / keyboard.type() → all key events
  • fill() → only final input/change
  • insertText() → no key events
  • evaluate() → no events

docs.title: Best for Reliability
docs.text: Scenario Best Method Entering text normally fill() Simulating human typing type() Sending keys (Enter, Tab) press() Bypassing event handlers insertText() UI not accepting input evaluate()

docs.title: 🎉 Final Recommendation
docs.text: Need Use Fast & clean fill() Realistic typing type() Keyboard shortcuts keyboard.press() Insert text with zero events keyboard.insertText() Hard input fields evaluate()

docs.title: What @playwright/test Provides
docs.text:
• Test runner — run tests with npx playwright test

  • Assertions — built-in assertion library like expect

  • Test hooks — beforeAll, beforeEach, afterEach, afterAll

  • Parallel test execution

  • Retries & timeouts per test

  • Reporter support — HTML, JSON, list, etc.

  • Browser projects — run tests in Chromium, Firefox, WebKit

docs.title: How It Looks in Code
docs.text:
// Import test runner and assertion library
const { test, expect } = require('@playwright/test');

// Define a test
test('Google search', async ({ page }) => {
  await page.goto('https://www.google.com');
  await page.fill('input[name="q"]', 'Playwright');
  await page.press('input[name="q"]', 'Enter');

  // Assert that results appear
  await expect(page.locator('#search')).toContainText('Playwright');
});

docs.title: Explanation:
docs.text:
• test → defines a test case

  • expect → assertions to validate conditions

  • { page } → test fixture provided by Playwright to interact with a browser page

docs.title: Why Use @playwright/test Instead of Plain Playwright
docs.text: Feature @playwright/test Plain Playwright Test runner ✅ Built-in ❌ No Assertions ✅ Built-in ❌ Requires third-party (Jest, Chai) Hooks ✅ Yes (beforeAll, afterEach) ❌ Manual setup Parallel execution ✅ Yes ❌ Extra configuration needed Reporting ✅ Built-in ❌ Requires external libraries

docs.title: Handling Multiple Tabs and Windows in Playwright (JavaScript)
docs.text: This document explains 7 real-world scenarios for handling multiple tabs and windows in Playwright with JavaScript. Each scenario includes: - Practical use case - Complete code snippet - Line-by-line explanation

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
Install Playwright:

npm init -y
npm install playwright

Import Playwright:

javascript
Copy code
const { chromium } = require('@playwright/test');

docs.title: Scenario 1: Handle New Tab Opened by Clicking a Link
User clicks a link (target="_blank") and a new tab opens.
docs.text:
Code
javascript
Copy code
// Launch browser
const browser = await chromium.launch();

// Create isolated browser context
const context = await browser.newContext();

// Open a new tab
const page = await context.newPage();

// Navigate to application
await page.goto('https://example.com');

// Capture the new tab opened on click
const [newPage] = await Promise.all([
  context.waitForEvent('page'),  // Waits for new tab
  page.click('a[target="_blank"]') // Action that opens new tab
]);

// Wait until new tab loads completely
await newPage.waitForLoadState();

// Print title of new tab
console.log(await newPage.title());

// Close browser
await browser.close();

docs.title: Explanation
docs.text:
• chromium.launch() → Starts browser

  • browser.newContext() → Creates fresh session

  • context.waitForEvent('page') → Detects new tab

  • Promise.all() → Avoids race condition

  • newPage → Reference to new tab

docs.title: Scenario 2: Switch Between Multiple Open Tabs
Application opens multiple tabs and user needs to switch between them.
docs.text:
Code
javascript
Copy code
// Get all open tabs
const pages = context.pages();

// Switch to second tab
await pages[1].bringToFront();
console.log(await pages[1].url());

// Switch back to first tab
await pages[0].bringToFront();

docs.title: Explanation
docs.text:
• context.pages() → Returns array of all tabs

  • bringToFront() → Brings tab into focus

  • Index represents tab order

docs.title: Clicking a button opens a popup window.
docs.text:
Code
javascript
Copy code
const [popup] = await Promise.all([
  page.waitForEvent('popup'), // Waits for popup window
  page.click('#printInvoice') // Action triggering popup
]);

// Wait for popup to load
await popup.waitForLoadState();

// Print popup title
console.log(await popup.title());

docs.title: Explanation
docs.text:
• page.waitForEvent('popup') → Captures popup window

  • Popup is linked to parent page automatically

  • Treated same as a normal page

docs.title: Scenario 4: Close Child Tab and Return to Parent Tab
Child tab opens → perform action → close it → return to parent.
docs.text:
Code
javascript
Copy code
// Store parent tab reference
const parentPage = page;

// Open child tab
const [childPage] = await Promise.all([
  context.waitForEvent('page'),
  page.click('#openChildTab')
]);

// Wait for child tab to load
await childPage.waitForLoadState();

// Close child tab
await childPage.close();

// Bring parent tab back to focus
await parentPage.bringToFront();

docs.title: Explanation
docs.text:
• Parent page reference is stored

  • Child page is captured and closed

  • Control is returned to parent tab

docs.title: Scenario 5: Switch to a Tab Based on Title
Multiple tabs are open → switch to required one using title.
docs.text:
Code
javascript
Copy code
for (const p of context.pages()) {
  const title = await p.title();

  if (title.includes('Dashboard')) {
    await p.bringToFront();
    break;
  }
}

docs.title: Explanation
docs.text:
• Iterates through all open tabs

  • Matches tab using title

  • Switches to correct tab

docs.title: Scenario 6: Handle OAuth / Google Login Window
Clicking "Login with Google" opens authentication window.
docs.text:
Code
javascript
Copy code
const [loginPage] = await Promise.all([
  context.waitForEvent('page'), // New OAuth window
  page.click('#googleLogin')    // Trigger login
]);

// Interact with login window
await loginPage.fill('#identifierId', 'test@gmail.com');
await loginPage.click('#identifierNext');

docs.title: Explanation
docs.text:
• OAuth login opens in new tab/window

  • New window is treated as normal page

  • Can interact using Playwright actions

docs.title: Open Admin / Reports page manually within same session.
docs.text:
Code
javascript
Copy code
// Create new tab manually
const adminPage = await context.newPage();

// Navigate to admin page
await adminPage.goto('https://admin.example.com');

docs.title: Explanation
docs.text:
• context.newPage() → Opens new tab

  • Shares cookies and session with existing tabs

docs.title: Best Practices
docs.text:
• Always use Promise.all() when handling new tabs

  • Prefer waitForEvent() over static waits

  • Close unused tabs to save memory

  • Validate title or URL before switching tabs

docs.title: Sample snipped code
docs.text:
test('@Child windows hadl', async ({browser})=>
 {
    const context = await browser.newContext();
    const page =  await context.newPage();
    const userName = page.locator('#username');
    await page.goto("https://rahulshettyacademy.com/loginpagePractise/");
    const documentLink = page.locator("[href*='documents-request']");

    const [newPage]=Promise.all(
   [
      context.waitForEvent('page'),//listen for any new page pending,rejected,fulfilled
      documentLink.click(),

   ])//new page is opened
    const  text = await newPage.locator(".red").textContent();
    const arrayText = text.split("@")
    const domain =  arrayText[1].split(" ")[0]
    console.log(domain);
    await page.locator("#username").fill(domain);
    console.log(await page.locator("#username").textContent());

docs.title: Data Query Language (DQL) – Part 3: Aggregations
docs.text: In this section, we will learn about aggregate functions in SQL: COUNT, SUM, AVG, GROUP BY, and HAVING.

docs.title: Sample Table: Orders
docs.text: OrderID Customer Product Quantity Price OrderDate 1 Amit Laptop 1 60000 2023-01-15 2 Riya Phone 2 20000 2023-01-20 3 Neha Laptop 1 60000 2023-02-05 4 Arjun Tablet 3 15000 2023-02-10 5 Priya Phone 1 20000 2023-02-18 6 Amit Tablet 2 15000 2023-03-01 7 Riya Laptop 1 60000 2023-03-12 8 Priya Phone 3 20000 2023-03-25 9 Arjun Laptop 2 60000 2023-04-02

docs.title: 1. COUNT – Number of Records
docs.text:
SELECT COUNT(*) AS TotalOrders
FROM Orders;

Output | TotalOrders | |-------------| | 9 |

docs.title: 2. SUM – Total Value
docs.text:
SELECT SUM(Price * Quantity) AS TotalRevenue
FROM Orders;

Output | TotalRevenue | |--------------| | 310000 |

docs.title: 3. AVG – Average Value
docs.text:
SELECT AVG(Price) AS AvgPrice
FROM Orders;

Output | AvgPrice | |----------| | 30000 |

docs.title: 4. GROUP BY – Aggregate Per Customer
docs.text:
SELECT Customer, COUNT(OrderID) AS OrdersPlaced
FROM Orders
GROUP BY Customer;

Output | Customer | OrdersPlaced | |----------|--------------| | Amit | 2 | | Riya | 2 | | Neha | 1 | | Arjun | 2 | | Priya | 2 |

docs.title: 5. GROUP BY with SUM
docs.text:
SELECT Product, SUM(Quantity) AS TotalSold
FROM Orders
GROUP BY Product;

Output | Product | TotalSold | |---------|-----------| | Laptop | 4 | | Phone | 6 | | Tablet | 5 |

docs.title: 6. HAVING – Filter Groups
docs.text:
SELECT Customer, SUM(Price * Quantity) AS TotalSpent
FROM Orders
GROUP BY Customer
HAVING SUM(Price * Quantity) > 50000;

Output | Customer | TotalSpent | |----------|------------| | Amit | 90000 | | Riya | 100000 | | Arjun | 150000 |

docs.title: 7. Complex Example 1 – Multiple Aggregates
docs.text:
SELECT Customer,
       COUNT(OrderID) AS OrdersCount,
       SUM(Price * Quantity) AS TotalSpent,
       AVG(Price) AS AvgProductPrice
FROM Orders
GROUP BY Customer;

Output | Customer | OrdersCount | TotalSpent | AvgProductPrice | |----------|-------------|------------|-----------------| | Amit | 2 | 90000 | 37500 | | Riya | 2 | 100000 | 40000 | | Neha | 1 | 60000 | 60000 | | Arjun | 2 | 150000 | 37500 | | Priya | 2 | 80000 | 20000 |

docs.title: 8. Complex Example 2 – Aggregation with Date Filtering
docs.text:
SELECT Product,
       SUM(Quantity) AS SoldInFeb,
       SUM(Price * Quantity) AS RevenueInFeb
FROM Orders
WHERE OrderDate BETWEEN '2023-02-01' AND '2023-02-28'
GROUP BY Product;

Output | Product | SoldInFeb | RevenueInFeb | |---------|-----------|--------------| | Laptop | 1 | 60000 | | Tablet | 3 | 45000 | | Phone | 1 | 20000 |

✅ In this part, we covered: - COUNT → Number of rows - SUM → Total values - AVG → Average values - GROUP BY → Aggregates per group - HAVING → Filter groups based on aggregate condition - Complex Queries → Multiple aggregates + filtering by date

docs.title: 🚦 Why Do We Need Constraints?
docs.text: Think of constraints as traffic rules for your database. - Without rules → cars can still move, but accidents happen. - With rules → movement is safe, organized, and predictable.

docs.title: Students Table
docs.text:
CREATE TABLE Students (
    id INT,
    firstname VARCHAR(50),
    lastname VARCHAR(50),
    address VARCHAR(100)
);

INSERT INTO Students (id, firstname, lastname, address) VALUES
(1, 'Rahul', 'Sharma', 'Pune'),
(1, 'Rahul', 'Sharma', 'Pune'),        -- Duplicate ID
(2, 'Priya', 'Verma', 'Mumbai'),
(3, NULL, 'Gupta', 'Delhi'),           -- Missing firstname
(4, 'Sneha', 'Patil', 'Bangalore'),
(5, 'Vikas', 'Kumar', 'Hyderabad'),
(5, 'Vikas', 'Kumar', 'Hyderabad');    -- Duplicate ID

docs.title: Marks Table
docs.text:
CREATE TABLE Marks (
    student_id INT,
    english INT,
    math INT,
    science INT,
    total_marks INT
);

INSERT INTO Marks (student_id, english, math, science, total_marks) VALUES
(1, 80, 90, 85, 255),
(2, 70, 75, 88, 233),
(100, 60, 65, 70, 195),                -- Orphan record
(3, 120, 50, 60, 230),                 -- Invalid marks > 100
(4, NULL, 40, 50, 90),                 -- Missing marks
(5, 88, 84, 91, 263),
(5, 88, 84, 91, 263);                  -- Duplicate row

docs.title: Sample Data Preview (Messy)
docs.text:
Students Table

id | firstname | lastname | address
---+-----------+----------+-----------
1  | Rahul     | Sharma   | Pune
1  | Rahul     | Sharma   | Pune       <-- Duplicate
2  | Priya     | Verma    | Mumbai
3  | NULL      | Gupta    | Delhi      <-- Missing firstname
4  | Sneha     | Patil    | Bangalore
5  | Vikas     | Kumar    | Hyderabad
5  | Vikas     | Kumar    | Hyderabad  <-- Duplicate

Marks Table

student_id | english | math | science | total_marks
-----------+---------+------+---------+-------------
1          | 80      | 90   | 85      | 255
2          | 70      | 75   | 88      | 233
100        | 60      | 65   | 70      | 195   <-- Orphan
3          | 120     | 50   | 60      | 230   <-- Invalid marks
4          | NULL    | 40   | 50      | 90    <-- Missing marks
5          | 88      | 84   | 91      | 263
5          | 88      | 84   | 91      | 263   <-- Duplicate

✅ These tables work fine, but without constraints problems can arise (duplicates, orphan records, missing data).

docs.title: 1. PRIMARY KEY
docs.text:
👉 Makes sure each row is unique and identifiable.

Without Primary Key

INSERT INTO Students (id, firstname, lastname, address)
VALUES (1, 'Rahul', 'Sharma', 'Pune');

INSERT INTO Students (id, firstname, lastname, address)
VALUES (1, 'AnotherRahul', 'Sharma', 'Pune'); -- Duplicate allowed

❌ Now two students with same ID exist → confusion in reports.

With Primary Key

id INT PRIMARY KEY

✅ Database stops duplicate rows.

docs.title: 2. FOREIGN KEY
docs.text:
👉 Ensures that a value in one table must exist in another.

Without Foreign Key

INSERT INTO Marks (student_id, english, math, science, total_marks)
VALUES (100, 80, 90, 85, 255); -- Student 100 doesn't exist

❌ Marks exist for a non-existent student (orphan record).

With Foreign Key

FOREIGN KEY (student_id) REFERENCES Students(id)

✅ Database prevents this.

docs.title: 3. UNIQUE
docs.text:
👉 Stops duplicate values in a column that should be unique (like email).

Without UNIQUE

INSERT INTO Students (id, firstname, lastname, address)
VALUES (7, 'Rohit', 'Sharma', 'Mumbai');

INSERT INTO Students (id, firstname, lastname, address)
VALUES (8, 'Rohit', 'Sharma', 'Mumbai'); -- Duplicate allowed

With UNIQUE

email VARCHAR(100) UNIQUE

✅ Database blocks duplicate emails.

docs.title: 4. NOT NULL
docs.text:
👉 Ensures important data is not left blank.

Without NOT NULL

INSERT INTO Students (id, firstname, lastname, address)
VALUES (9, NULL, 'Sharma', 'Delhi'); -- Allowed

❌ Student without a name → makes no sense.

With NOT NULL

firstname VARCHAR(50) NOT NULL

✅ Database forces valid data.

docs.title: ✅ Summary in Easy Words
docs.text:
• Primary Key → Every row should have a unique ID → No duplicates.
  • Foreign Key → Links two tables → No orphan data.
  • Unique → Prevents duplicate values.
  • Not Null → Some fields must always have a value.

👉 Without constraints → data looks fine in the beginning but later causes duplicates, orphan rows, missing data, wrong ETL reports.

docs.title: 🔹 What is DCL?
docs.text: DCL commands are used to control access and permissions in a database. They define who can access, modify, or manage database objects.

docs.title: 1. GRANT
docs.text:
• Provides privileges to a user.
GRANT SELECT, INSERT ON Employee TO user1;

docs.title: 2. REVOKE
docs.text:
• Removes previously granted privileges.
REVOKE INSERT ON Employee FROM user1;

docs.title: 3. DENY (SQL Server)
docs.text:
• Explicitly denies permission to users.
DENY DELETE ON Employee TO user1;

docs.title: ✅ Pros
docs.text:
1. Security → Ensures only authorized users access data.
  2. Granularity → Assign specific privileges per object.
  3. Control → Manage roles and user access.
  4. Scalability → Assign privileges to roles for teams.

docs.title: ❌ Cons
docs.text:
1. Mismanagement Risk → Wrong grants expose sensitive data.
  2. Complexity → Hard to manage in large organizations.
  3. Performance Overhead → Checking permissions for each query.
  4. Inconsistency → Syntax varies across databases.

docs.title: ✅ Summary Table
docs.text: Command Purpose Rollback Possible Example Usage GRANT Give permissions ✅ Yes Allow SELECT on Employee REVOKE Remove permissions ✅ Yes Remove INSERT privilege DENY Explicitly block access ✅ Yes Prevent DELETE on Employee

docs.title: 📊 DCL Commands – Feature Comparison
docs.text: Command Rollback Data Loss Structure Change Typical Use Case GRANT ✅ Yes ❌ No ❌ No Provide privileges REVOKE ✅ Yes ❌ No ❌ No Remove privileges DENY ✅ Yes ❌ No ❌ No Restrict user actions

docs.title: 🔹 What is DDL?
docs.text:
DDL commands are used to define, modify, and manage the structure of database objects (like tables, views, schemas, indexes).

These commands work at the schema level (structure), not on individual rows of data.

docs.title: 1. CREATE
docs.text:
• Used to create database objects such as tables, schemas, views, or indexes.
  • You must define the structure (columns, data types, constraints).

Example 

CREATE TABLE Employee (
    EmpID INT PRIMARY KEY,
    Name VARCHAR(100) NOT NULL,
    Salary DECIMAL(10,2) CHECK (Salary > 0),
    DepartmentID INT,
    HireDate DATE DEFAULT CURRENT_DATE
);

docs.title: 2. ALTER
docs.text:
• Used to modify existing objects (add/remove/rename columns, change data types, add constraints).

Example 

-- Add a new column
ALTER TABLE Employee ADD Age INT;

-- Modify column type
ALTER TABLE Employee MODIFY Salary DECIMAL(12,2);

-- Drop a column
ALTER TABLE Employee DROP COLUMN Age;

-- Add a foreign key
ALTER TABLE Employee
ADD CONSTRAINT fk_dept FOREIGN KEY (DepartmentID) REFERENCES Department(DeptID);

docs.title: 3. DROP
docs.text:
• Deletes a database object completely (table, view, database, index).
  • ⚠️ Removes structure and all data.

Example 

DROP TABLE Employee;
DROP DATABASE HR;

docs.title: 4. TRUNCATE
docs.text:
• Removes all rows from a table, but keeps the structure.
  • Much faster than DELETE (no logging of each row).
  • Cannot be rolled back in some DBs.

Example 

TRUNCATE TABLE Employee;

docs.title: 5. RENAME
docs.text:
• Renames a database object (varies slightly across RDBMS).

Example (MySQL / Oracle) 

RENAME TABLE Employee TO Staff;

docs.title: 6. COMMENT
docs.text:
• Add descriptions to database objects. (Supported in Oracle, PostgreSQL, etc.)

Example 

COMMENT ON TABLE Employee IS 'Stores employee details';
COMMENT ON COLUMN Employee.Salary IS 'Monthly Salary in INR';

docs.title: ✅ Pros
docs.text:
1. Schema Control → DDL provides strong control over database design (tables, keys, indexes).
  2. Integrity Enforcement → Constraints (PRIMARY KEY, FOREIGN KEY, CHECK) ensure data accuracy.
  3. Performance → With indexes and partitions defined via DDL, queries become faster.
  4. Automation Friendly → You can version-control DDL scripts for CI/CD pipelines.
  5. Flexibility → Easily modify structures as business needs evolve.

docs.title: ❌ Cons
docs.text:
1. Destructive Nature
  2. DROP and TRUNCATE permanently remove data (can’t easily rollback).

  3. Small mistake → huge data loss.

  4. Locking Issues

  5. Some DDL operations lock tables (no read/write allowed until completed).

  6. Dependent Objects

  7. Dropping/altering tables can break views, stored procedures, or queries that depend on them.

  8. Environment Differences

  9. Syntax varies across RDBMS (MySQL, Oracle, PostgreSQL). Example: ALTER column syntax differs.

  10. Not Transaction-Safe (in some DBs)

  11. In MySQL, some DDL operations auto-commit → cannot be rolled back.

docs.title: 1. Schema Control
docs.text:
DDL lets you define strong structures with relationships.

CREATE TABLE Department (
    DeptID INT PRIMARY KEY,
    DeptName VARCHAR(50) UNIQUE
);

CREATE TABLE Employee (
    EmpID INT PRIMARY KEY,
    Name VARCHAR(100) NOT NULL,
    Salary DECIMAL(10,2),
    DeptID INT,
    FOREIGN KEY (DeptID) REFERENCES Department(DeptID)
);

👉 Employees must belong to a valid department.

docs.title: 2. Integrity Enforcement
docs.text:
Constraints enforce data accuracy.

CREATE TABLE Employee (
    EmpID INT PRIMARY KEY,
    Name VARCHAR(100) NOT NULL,
    Salary DECIMAL(10,2) CHECK (Salary > 0),
    DeptID INT NOT NULL,
    FOREIGN KEY (DeptID) REFERENCES Department(DeptID)
);

👉 Prevents negative salaries and missing departments.

docs.title: 3. Performance (Indexes & Partitions)
docs.text:
Indexes and partitions improve query speed.

-- Index for faster salary searches
CREATE INDEX idx_salary ON Employee(Salary);

-- Partition sales table by year
CREATE TABLE Sales (
    SaleID INT PRIMARY KEY,
    SaleDate DATE,
    Amount DECIMAL(10,2)
)
PARTITION BY RANGE (YEAR(SaleDate)) (
    PARTITION p2023 VALUES LESS THAN (2024),
    PARTITION p2024 VALUES LESS THAN (2025)
);

👉 Queries on salaries or specific years run faster.

docs.title: 4. Automation Friendly (CI/CD)
docs.text:
DDL scripts can be stored and executed in deployments.

-- migration_v2.sql
ALTER TABLE Employee ADD COLUMN Email VARCHAR(100);

👉 Keeps dev, test, and prod in sync automatically.

docs.title: 5. Flexibility (Evolving Structures)
docs.text:
Easily adapt schema to new business needs.

ALTER TABLE Employee ADD COLUMN PhoneNumber VARCHAR(15);
ALTER TABLE Employee RENAME COLUMN Name TO FullName;

👉 Business changes are easily handled.

docs.title: ✅ Summary Table
docs.text: Advantage What it Means Example Schema Control Strong control over tables, keys, relationships Employee → Department with foreign key Integrity Enforcement Constraints ensure only valid data CHECK (Salary > 0), NOT NULL Performance Indexes & partitions speed up queries CREATE INDEX idx_salary Automation Friendly DDL scripts can be versioned in Git & run in CI/CD Migration scripts for deployments Flexibility Schema can evolve with business needs ALTER TABLE Employee ADD PhoneNumber

docs.title: 📊 DDL Commands – Feature Comparison
docs.text: Command Rollback Possible Data Loss Structure Change Typical Use Case CREATE ✅ Yes (before commit) ❌ No ✅ Creates new object Create tables, views, indexes ALTER ✅ Yes (before commit) ❌ No ✅ Modifies structure Add/modify columns, constraints DROP ✅ Yes (before commit) ✅ Yes (all data lost) ✅ Removes object completely Delete table/schema permanently TRUNCATE ✅ Yes (before commit) ✅ Yes (all rows deleted) ❌ No (structure remains) Quickly remove all records RENAME ✅ Yes (before commit) ❌ No ✅ Only name changes Rename table/column COMMENT ✅ Yes (before commit) ❌ No ❌ No (metadata only) Add description to objects CREATE INDEX ✅ Yes (before commit) ❌ No ✅ Creates performance structure Improve query performance DROP INDEX ✅ Yes (before commit) ❌ No (only index removed) ✅ Removes performance structure Free up space, remove unused index

docs.title: 🔑 Key Notes
docs.text:
• Rollback → Possible only until you COMMIT (some DBs auto-commit DDL, e.g., Oracle).
  • Data Loss → DROP & TRUNCATE cause data removal; ALTER/RENAME don’t.
  • Structure Change → All DDL affects schema except COMMENT.
  • Performance Impact → TRUNCATE is faster than DELETE; indexes speed queries but slow inserts/updates.

docs.title: 🔹 What is DML?
docs.text: DML commands are used to manipulate and manage the data stored inside database tables. Unlike DDL, which defines the schema, DML works on the actual rows (records) inside the tables.

docs.title: 1. INSERT
docs.text:
• Adds new records into a table.
INSERT INTO Employee (EmpID, Name, Salary)
VALUES (101, 'Amit Sharma', 55000.00);

docs.title: 2. UPDATE
docs.text:
• Modifies existing records.
UPDATE Employee
SET Salary = Salary + 5000
WHERE EmpID = 101;

docs.title: 3. DELETE
docs.text:
• Removes records from a table.
DELETE FROM Employee WHERE EmpID = 101;

docs.title: 4. MERGE (UPSERT)
docs.text:
• Combines INSERT + UPDATE + DELETE in one.
MERGE INTO Employee AS E
USING NewEmployee AS N
ON (E.EmpID = N.EmpID)
WHEN MATCHED THEN
    UPDATE SET E.Salary = N.Salary
WHEN NOT MATCHED THEN
    INSERT (EmpID, Name, Salary) VALUES (N.EmpID, N.Name, N.Salary);

docs.title: ✅ Pros
docs.text:
1. Direct Data Control → Can manipulate specific rows.
  2. Flexible → SELECT with filters, joins, aggregations.
  3. Transaction Safe → Rollback possible.
  4. Granular → Row-level operations.

docs.title: ❌ Cons
docs.text:
1. Data Loss Risk → UPDATE/DELETE without WHERE affects all rows.
  2. Performance Issues → Large queries slow performance.
  3. Locking Problems → Concurrent transactions may cause locks.
  4. Index Dependency → Without indexes, queries may be slow.

docs.title: ✅ Summary Table
docs.text: Command Purpose Rollback Possible Example Usage INSERT Add new records ✅ Yes Add employee UPDATE Modify existing records ✅ Yes Increase salary DELETE Remove records ✅ Yes Delete inactive employee MERGE Insert/Update/Delete in one ✅ Yes Sync staging & prod data

docs.title: 📊 DML Commands – Feature Comparison
docs.text: Command Rollback Data Loss Risk Structure Change Typical Use Case INSERT ✅ Yes ❌ No ❌ No Add new data UPDATE ✅ Yes ⚠️ Yes ❌ No Modify existing data DELETE ✅ Yes ⚠️ Yes ❌ No Remove rows MERGE ✅ Yes ⚠️ Possible ❌ No Sync datasets efficiently

docs.title: Data Query Language (DQL) – Part 1: Basics
docs.text: In this section, we will learn the basics of SELECT: filtering, pattern matching, sorting, distinct values, and aliases.

docs.title: Sample Table: Employee
docs.text: EmpID Name Department Salary HireDate 101 Amit Sharma HR 50000 2020-01-15 102 Riya Mehta IT 65000 2021-03-22 103 Arjun Rao Finance 55000 2019-07-09 104 Neha Singh IT 75000 2022-05-01 105 Rohit Verma HR 48000 2023-02-10 106 Priya Nair IT 65000 2020-12-11

docs.title: 2. WHERE – Filter Rows
docs.text:
SELECT Name, Department, Salary
FROM Employee
WHERE Department = 'IT';

Output | Name | Department | Salary | |------------|------------|--------| | Riya Mehta | IT | 65000 | | Neha Singh | IT | 75000 | | Priya Nair | IT | 65000 |

docs.title: a) Starts With Pattern
docs.text:
SELECT Name FROM Employee
WHERE Name LIKE 'R%';

Output | Name | |-------------| | Riya Mehta | | Rohit Verma |

docs.title: b) Ends With Pattern
docs.text:
SELECT Name FROM Employee
WHERE Name LIKE '%a';

Output | Name | |------------| | Riya Mehta | | Priya Nair |

docs.title: c) Contains Substring
docs.text:
SELECT Name FROM Employee
WHERE Name LIKE '%Singh%';

Output | Name | |------------| | Neha Singh |

docs.title: d) Single Character Wildcard (_)
docs.text:
SELECT Name FROM Employee
WHERE Name LIKE '_mit%';

Output | Name | |-------------| | Amit Sharma |

docs.title: e) Combined Pattern
docs.text:
SELECT Name FROM Employee
WHERE Name LIKE 'R%a';

Output | Name | |------------| | Riya Mehta | | Priya Nair |

docs.title: 4. ORDER BY – Sort Results
docs.text:
SELECT Name, Salary
FROM Employee
ORDER BY Salary DESC;

Output | Name | Salary | |------------|--------| | Neha Singh | 75000 | | Riya Mehta | 65000 | | Priya Nair | 65000 | | Arjun Rao | 55000 | | Amit Sharma| 50000 | | Rohit Verma| 48000 |

docs.title: 5. DISTINCT – Unique Values
docs.text:
SELECT DISTINCT Department
FROM Employee;

Output | Department | |------------| | HR | | IT | | Finance |

docs.title: 6. ALIASES – Renaming Columns
docs.text:
SELECT Name AS EmployeeName,
       Salary AS MonthlySalary
FROM Employee;

Output | EmployeeName | MonthlySalary | |--------------|---------------| | Amit Sharma | 50000 | | Riya Mehta | 65000 | | Arjun Rao | 55000 | | Neha Singh | 75000 | | Rohit Verma | 48000 | | Priya Nair | 65000 |

✅ In this part, we covered: - SELECT * → Fetch all columns - WHERE → Filter rows - LIKE → Pattern matching (starts, ends, contains, single char, combined) - ORDER BY → Sort results - DISTINCT → Get unique values - ALIASES → Rename output columns

Next: Part 2 (Joins) – Learn INNER JOIN, LEFT JOIN, RIGHT JOIN, FULL JOIN with multiple tables.

docs.title: 🔹 What is DQL?
docs.text: DQL commands are used to retrieve data from database tables. It primarily deals with queries to fetch results.

docs.title: 1. SELECT
docs.text:
• Fetches data from tables with conditions, joins, and aggregations.
-- Get all employees
SELECT * FROM Employee;

-- Get employees with salary > 50k
SELECT Name, Salary FROM Employee WHERE Salary > 50000;

-- Aggregation
SELECT DepartmentID, AVG(Salary) AS AvgSalary
FROM Employee
GROUP BY DepartmentID
HAVING AVG(Salary) > 50000;

docs.title: ✅ Pros
docs.text:
1. Powerful Retrieval → Fetch specific or aggregated data.
  2. Flexible Queries → Supports joins, subqueries, aggregations.
  3. Analytics Ready → Ideal for reporting.
  4. Safe → Does not modify data (read-only).

docs.title: ❌ Cons
docs.text:
1. Performance Impact → Complex queries may be slow.
  2. Requires Indexes → To optimize performance.
  3. Read-only → Cannot insert/update/delete.
  4. Locks → Long-running queries can block resources.

docs.title: ✅ Summary Table
docs.text: Command Purpose Rollback Possible Example Usage SELECT Retrieve data (query) N/A Get employees

docs.title: 📊 DQL Command – Feature Comparison
docs.text: Command Rollback Data Loss Structure Change Typical Use Case SELECT N/A ❌ No ❌ No Fetch rows of data

docs.title: Data Query Language (DQL) – Part 2: Joins
docs.text: In this section, we will learn INNER JOIN, LEFT JOIN, RIGHT JOIN, and FULL JOIN with clear inputs and outputs. We’ll use four sample tables: Employees, Departments, Projects, EmployeeProject.

docs.title: Employees
docs.text: EmpID Name DeptID 101 Amit Sharma 1 102 Riya Mehta 2 103 Arjun Rao 3 104 Neha Singh 2 105 Rohit Verma nan 106 Priya Nair 5

docs.title: Departments
docs.text: DeptID DeptName 1 HR 2 IT 3 Finance 4 Marketing

docs.title: Projects
docs.text: ProjID ProjName DeptID 201 Portal Revamp 2 202 Payroll Cleanup 3 203 Hiring Sprint 1 204 Brand Campaign 4

docs.title: 1) INNER JOIN – Only matching rows in both tables
docs.text:
Get each employee’s department name (employees without department are excluded).

SELECT e.EmpID, e.Name, d.DeptName
FROM Employees e
INNER JOIN Departments d ON e.DeptID = d.DeptID
ORDER BY e.EmpID;

Output | EmpID | Name | DeptName | |--------:|:------------|:-----------| | 101 | Amit Sharma | HR | | 102 | Riya Mehta | IT | | 103 | Arjun Rao | Finance | | 104 | Neha Singh | IT |

docs.title: 2) LEFT JOIN – All rows from left (Employees), matched Departments if any
docs.text:
Shows all employees; missing departments appear as NULL.

SELECT e.EmpID, e.Name, d.DeptName
FROM Employees e
LEFT JOIN Departments d ON e.DeptID = d.DeptID
ORDER BY e.EmpID;

Output | EmpID | Name | DeptName | |--------:|:------------|:-----------| | 101 | Amit Sharma | HR | | 102 | Riya Mehta | IT | | 103 | Arjun Rao | Finance | | 104 | Neha Singh | IT | | 105 | Rohit Verma | nan | | 106 | Priya Nair | nan |

docs.title: 3) RIGHT JOIN – All rows from right (Departments), matched Employees if any
docs.text:
Shows all departments; departments without employees show NULLs for employee columns.

SELECT d.DeptID, d.DeptName, e.EmpID, e.Name
FROM Employees e
RIGHT JOIN Departments d ON e.DeptID = d.DeptID
ORDER BY d.DeptID, e.EmpID;

Output | DeptID | DeptName | EmpID | Name | |---------:|:-----------|--------:|:------------| | 1 | HR | 101 | Amit Sharma | | 2 | IT | 102 | Riya Mehta | | 2 | IT | 104 | Neha Singh | | 3 | Finance | 103 | Arjun Rao | | 4 | Marketing | nan | nan |

docs.title: 4) FULL OUTER JOIN – All rows from both sides
docs.text:
Includes employees without departments and departments without employees.

Note: Some databases (e.g., MySQL) don’t support FULL JOIN. You can emulate it using LEFT JOIN UNION RIGHT JOIN.

-- Standard syntax (supported in SQL Server, PostgreSQL, etc.)
SELECT e.EmpID, e.Name, e.DeptID, d.DeptName
FROM Employees e
FULL OUTER JOIN Departments d ON e.DeptID = d.DeptID
ORDER BY e.DeptID, e.EmpID;

-- MySQL-compatible workaround
SELECT e.EmpID, e.Name, e.DeptID, d.DeptName
FROM Employees e
LEFT JOIN Departments d ON e.DeptID = d.DeptID
UNION
SELECT e.EmpID, e.Name, e.DeptID, d.DeptName
FROM Employees e
RIGHT JOIN Departments d ON e.DeptID = d.DeptID
ORDER BY DeptID, EmpID;

Output | EmpID | Name | DeptID | DeptName | |--------:|:------------|---------:|:-----------| | 101 | Amit Sharma | 1 | HR | | 102 | Riya Mehta | 2 | IT | | 104 | Neha Singh | 2 | IT | | 103 | Arjun Rao | 3 | Finance | | nan | nan | 4 | Marketing | | 106 | Priya Nair | 5 | nan | | 105 | Rohit Verma | nan | nan |

docs.title: 5) INNER JOIN with filter + ordering
docs.text:
Employees in IT or Finance, sorted by department then name.

SELECT e.Name, d.DeptName, e.EmpID
FROM Employees e
INNER JOIN Departments d ON e.DeptID = d.DeptID
WHERE d.DeptName IN ('IT','Finance')
ORDER BY d.DeptName, e.Name;

Output | Name | DeptName | EmpID | |:-----------|:-----------|--------:| | Arjun Rao | Finance | 103 | | Neha Singh | IT | 104 | | Riya Mehta | IT | 102 |

docs.title: Complex A) Multi-join + Aggregation
docs.text:
Total hours and unique contributors per project and department.

SELECT d.DeptName,
       p.ProjName,
       SUM(ep.Hours)    AS TotalHours,
       COUNT(DISTINCT e.EmpID) AS Contributors
FROM EmployeeProject ep
JOIN Employees e   ON ep.EmpID = e.EmpID
JOIN Projects  p   ON ep.ProjID = p.ProjID
LEFT JOIN Departments d ON p.DeptID = d.DeptID
GROUP BY d.DeptName, p.ProjName
ORDER BY d.DeptName, p.ProjName;

Output | DeptName | ProjName | TotalHours | Contributors | |:-----------|:----------------|-------------:|---------------:| | Finance | Payroll Cleanup | 25 | 1 | | HR | Hiring Sprint | 20 | 1 | | IT | Portal Revamp | 90 | 3 | | Marketing | Brand Campaign | 10 | 1 |

docs.title: Complex B) Self-join – Coworker pairs in the same department
docs.text:
List all unique pairs of employees who are in the same department (NULL departments excluded).

SELECT a.DeptID, a.Name AS EmployeeA, b.Name AS EmployeeB
FROM Employees a
JOIN Employees b ON a.DeptID = b.DeptID AND a.EmpID < b.EmpID
WHERE a.DeptID IS NOT NULL
ORDER BY a.DeptID, EmployeeA, EmployeeB;

Output | DeptID | EmployeeA | EmployeeB | |---------:|:------------|:------------| | 2 | Riya Mehta | Neha Singh |

✅ In this part, we covered: - INNER JOIN → Only matching rows - LEFT JOIN → All left rows + matches - RIGHT JOIN → All right rows + matches - FULL JOIN → All rows from both sides (with MySQL workaround) - Complex joins → Multi-table joins with aggregation; Self-join for peer relationships

docs.title: SQL Commands: DDL, DML, DQL, TCL, DCL
📌 Types of SQL Commands
docs.text: SQL commands are divided into 5 main categories:

docs.title: 1. DDL (Data Definition Language)
docs.text: 👉 Used to define and manage the structure of the database (tables, schemas, indexes).

docs.title: Commands:
docs.text:
• CREATE → Create new objects (table, view, database, etc.)
  • ALTER → Modify structure of existing objects
  • DROP → Delete objects
  • TRUNCATE → Remove all rows from a table (faster than DELETE, no rollback in some DBs)
  • COMMENT → Add comments to schema objects
  • RENAME → Rename objects

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
-- Create a new table
CREATE TABLE Employee (
    EmpID INT PRIMARY KEY,
    Name VARCHAR(50),
    Salary DECIMAL(10,2),
    Department VARCHAR(30)
);

-- Alter the table
ALTER TABLE Employee ADD Age INT;

-- Drop the table
DROP TABLE Employee;

-- Remove all records but keep structure
TRUNCATE TABLE Employee;

docs.title: 2. DML (Data Manipulation Language)
docs.text: 👉 Used to manage and modify the data inside tables.

docs.title: Commands:
docs.text:
• INSERT → Insert new records
  • UPDATE → Modify existing records
  • DELETE → Remove records
  • MERGE (in some DBs) → Insert/Update simultaneously

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
-- Insert data
INSERT INTO Employee (EmpID, Name, Salary, Department, Age)
VALUES (101, 'John Doe', 55000, 'IT', 28);

-- Update data
UPDATE Employee
SET Salary = 60000
WHERE EmpID = 101;

-- Delete a record
DELETE FROM Employee WHERE EmpID = 101;

docs.title: 3. DQL (Data Query Language)
docs.text: 👉 Used to fetch/query data from database.

docs.title: Command:
docs.text: • SELECT

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
-- Select all data
SELECT * FROM Employee;

-- Select specific columns
SELECT Name, Salary FROM Employee;

-- Select with condition
SELECT * FROM Employee WHERE Department = 'IT';

docs.title: 4. TCL (Transaction Control Language)
docs.text: 👉 Used to manage transactions (groups of SQL statements).

docs.title: Commands:
docs.text:
• COMMIT → Save changes permanently
  • ROLLBACK → Undo changes
  • SAVEPOINT → Set a point to rollback later
  • SET TRANSACTION → Set transaction properties

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
BEGIN TRANSACTION;

UPDATE Employee SET Salary = Salary + 5000 WHERE Department = 'IT';

-- If everything is fine
COMMIT;

-- If error, rollback
ROLLBACK;

docs.title: 5. DCL (Data Control Language)
docs.text: 👉 Used to control access (security/permissions).

docs.title: Commands:
docs.text:
• GRANT → Give permissions
  • REVOKE → Take back permissions

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
-- Grant permission
GRANT SELECT, INSERT ON Employee TO user1;

-- Revoke permission
REVOKE INSERT ON Employee FROM user1;

docs.title: ✅ Quick Summary Table
docs.text: Type Full Form Purpose Examples DDL Data Definition Language Define database objects CREATE, ALTER, DROP, TRUNCATE DML Data Manipulation Language Modify data INSERT, UPDATE, DELETE DQL Data Query Language Query data SELECT TCL Transaction Control Language Manage transactions COMMIT, ROLLBACK, SAVEPOINT DCL Data Control Language Control access GRANT, REVOKE

docs.title: Basic SQL Practice with Explanations
docs.text:
This file contains 20 SQL practice problems covering: - SELECT, FROM, WHERE - ORDER BY - DISTINCT - LIMIT / TOP / ROWNUM

Each question includes: - Input Table(s) - Question - SQL Query - Explanation - Output Table

docs.title: Q1: Fetch employees from department HR
docs.text:
Input Table: employees | emp_id | name | dept | salary | |--------|---------|-------|--------| | 1 | Alice | HR | 50000 | | 2 | Bob | IT | 60000 | | 3 | Charlie | HR | 55000 | | 4 | David | Sales | 45000 |

Query:

SELECT emp_id, name, dept, salary
FROM employees
WHERE dept = 'HR';

Explanation: We used WHERE dept = 'HR' to filter only HR employees.

Output: | emp_id | name | dept | salary | |--------|---------|------|--------| | 1 | Alice | HR | 50000 | | 3 | Charlie | HR | 55000 |

docs.title: Q2: Fetch employees earning more than 55,000
docs.text:
Query:

SELECT name, salary
FROM employees
WHERE salary > 55000;

Explanation: > operator filters salaries above 55,000.

Output: | name | salary | |------|--------| | Bob | 60000 |

docs.title: Q3: Employees from IT or Sales department
docs.text:
Query:

SELECT * 
FROM employees
WHERE dept IN ('IT', 'Sales');

Explanation: The IN operator checks if dept is one of the listed values.

Output: | emp_id | name | dept | salary | |--------|-------|-------|--------| | 2 | Bob | IT | 60000 | | 4 | David | Sales | 45000 |

docs.title: Q4: Employees not in HR
docs.text:
Query:

SELECT name, dept
FROM employees
WHERE dept <> 'HR';

Explanation: <> means NOT EQUAL.

Output: | name | dept | |-------|-------| | Bob | IT | | David | Sales |

docs.title: Q5: Fetch employee with emp_id = 2
docs.text:
Query:

SELECT * 
FROM employees
WHERE emp_id = 2;

Explanation: Simple filter on primary key.

Output: | emp_id | name | dept | salary | |--------|------|------|--------| | 2 | Bob | IT | 60000 |

docs.title: Q6: Sort employees by salary ascending
docs.text:
Query:

SELECT name, salary
FROM employees
ORDER BY salary ASC;

Explanation: Default is ascending. Employees ordered by lowest salary first.

Output: | name | salary | |---------|--------| | David | 45000 | | Alice | 50000 | | Charlie | 55000 | | Bob | 60000 |

docs.title: Q7: Sort employees by salary descending
docs.text:
Query:

SELECT name, salary
FROM employees
ORDER BY salary DESC;

Explanation: DESC shows highest salary first.

Output: | name | salary | |---------|--------| | Bob | 60000 | | Charlie | 55000 | | Alice | 50000 | | David | 45000 |

docs.title: Q8: Sort employees by department, then salary
docs.text:
Query:

SELECT name, dept, salary
FROM employees
ORDER BY dept ASC, salary DESC;

Explanation: First sort alphabetically by dept, then within dept sort by salary high-to-low.

Output: | name | dept | salary | |---------|-------|--------| | Alice | HR | 50000 | | Charlie | HR | 55000 | | Bob | IT | 60000 | | David | Sales | 45000 |

docs.title: Q9: Sort by name alphabetically
docs.text:
Query:

SELECT * 
FROM employees
ORDER BY name;

Explanation: Alphabetical sort on name column.

Output: | emp_id | name | dept | salary | |--------|---------|-------|--------| | 1 | Alice | HR | 50000 | | 2 | Bob | IT | 60000 | | 3 | Charlie | HR | 55000 | | 4 | David | Sales | 45000 |

docs.title: Q10: Sort by length of name
docs.text:
Query:

SELECT name, LENGTH(name) AS name_length
FROM employees
ORDER BY name_length;

Explanation: We calculated length of name, then ordered by it.

Output: | name | name_length | |---------|-------------| | Bob | 3 | | Alice | 5 | | David | 5 | | Charlie | 7 |

docs.title: Q11: List unique departments
docs.text:
Query:

SELECT DISTINCT dept
FROM employees;

Explanation: Removes duplicate department names.

Output: | dept | |-------| | HR | | IT | | Sales |

docs.title: Q12: Unique salary values
docs.text:
Query:

SELECT DISTINCT salary
FROM employees;

Explanation: Shows only unique salary numbers.

Output: | salary | |--------| | 50000 | | 60000 | | 55000 | | 45000 |

docs.title: Q13: Unique combinations of dept and salary
docs.text:
Query:

SELECT DISTINCT dept, salary
FROM employees;

Explanation: Checks uniqueness across multiple columns.

Output: | dept | salary | |-------|--------| | HR | 50000 | | HR | 55000 | | IT | 60000 | | Sales | 45000 |

docs.title: Q14: Unique first letters of names
docs.text:
Query:

SELECT DISTINCT SUBSTR(name,1,1) AS first_letter
FROM employees;

Explanation: Takes the first character from each name and removes duplicates.

Output: | first_letter | |--------------| | A | | B | | C | | D |

docs.title: Q15: Unique job roles (assume another column exists)
docs.text:
Input Table with job column: | emp_id | name | dept | salary | job | |--------|---------|-------|--------|------------| | 1 | Alice | HR | 50000 | Analyst | | 2 | Bob | IT | 60000 | Developer | | 3 | Charlie | HR | 55000 | Analyst | | 4 | David | Sales | 45000 | Sales Rep |

Query:

SELECT DISTINCT job
FROM employees;

Output: | job | |-----------| | Analyst | | Developer | | Sales Rep |

docs.title: Q16: Get first 2 employees
docs.text:
Query (MySQL/Postgres):

SELECT * 
FROM employees
LIMIT 2;

Explanation: Fetches only first 2 rows.

Output: | emp_id | name | dept | salary | |--------|-------|------|--------| | 1 | Alice | HR | 50000 | | 2 | Bob | IT | 60000 |

docs.title: Q17: Get top 1 highest salary employee (SQL Server)
docs.text:
Query:

SELECT TOP 1 name, salary
FROM employees
ORDER BY salary DESC;

Explanation: SQL Server uses TOP instead of LIMIT.

Output: | name | salary | |------|--------| | Bob | 60000 |

docs.title: Q18: Get employees with ROWNUM <= 3 (Oracle)
docs.text:
Query:

SELECT * 
FROM employees
WHERE ROWNUM <= 3;

Explanation: Oracle uses ROWNUM pseudo column.

Output: | emp_id | name | dept | salary | |--------|---------|------|--------| | 1 | Alice | HR | 50000 | | 2 | Bob | IT | 60000 | | 3 | Charlie | HR | 55000 |

docs.title: Q19: Get top 2 employees by salary (Postgres)
docs.text:
Query:

SELECT name, salary
FROM employees
ORDER BY salary DESC
LIMIT 2;

Explanation: Orders by salary then limits to 2.

Output: | name | salary | |---------|--------| | Bob | 60000 | | Charlie | 55000 |

docs.title: Q20: Skip first 1 row and fetch next 2 (OFFSET)
docs.text:
Query (Postgres):

SELECT name, salary
FROM employees
ORDER BY emp_id
OFFSET 1 ROWS FETCH NEXT 2 ROWS ONLY;

Explanation: Skips first record and fetches next 2.

Output: | name | salary | |---------|--------| | Bob | 60000 | | Charlie | 55000 |

docs.title: SQL Practice: Filtering & Conditions with Explanations
docs.text:
This file contains 20 SQL practice problems covering filtering and conditional operators:

  • Comparison operators: =, <>, >, <, >=, <=
  • Logical operators: AND, OR, NOT
  • BETWEEN, IN, LIKE
  • IS NULL / IS NOT NULL

Each question includes:

  • Input Table(s)
  • Question
  • SQL Query
  • Explanation
  • Output Table

docs.title: Q1: Employees with salary = 50000
docs.text:
Input Table: employees

emp_id name dept salary 1 Alice HR 50000 2 Bob IT 60000 3 Charlie HR 55000 4 David Sales 45000

Query:

SELECT *
FROM employees
WHERE salary = 50000;

Explanation: = operator selects rows where salary equals 50000.

Output:

emp_id name dept salary 1 Alice HR 50000

docs.title: Q2: Employees with salary <> 60000
docs.text:
SELECT *
FROM employees
WHERE salary <> 60000;

Explanation: <> selects rows not equal to 60000.

Output:

emp_id name dept salary 1 Alice HR 50000 3 Charlie HR 55000 4 David Sales 45000

docs.title: Q3: Employees with salary > 50000
docs.text:
SELECT name, salary
FROM employees
WHERE salary > 50000;

Explanation: > selects rows with salary greater than 50000.

Output:

name salary Bob 60000 Charlie 55000

docs.title: Q4: Employees with salary <= 50000
docs.text:
SELECT name, salary
FROM employees
WHERE salary <= 50000;

Explanation: <= selects salaries less than or equal to 50000.

Output:

name salary Alice 50000 David 45000

docs.title: Q5: Employees with salary >= 55000
docs.text:
SELECT *
FROM employees
WHERE salary >= 55000;

Explanation: >= selects salaries 55000 or more.

Output:

emp_id name dept salary 2 Bob IT 60000 3 Charlie HR 55000

docs.title: Q6: Employees in HR AND salary > 50000
docs.text:
SELECT *
FROM employees
WHERE dept = 'HR' AND salary > 50000;

Explanation: AND ensures both conditions are true.

Output:

emp_id name dept salary 3 Charlie HR 55000

docs.title: Q7: Employees in HR OR salary > 55000
docs.text:
SELECT *
FROM employees
WHERE dept = 'HR' OR salary > 55000;

Explanation: OR selects rows matching either condition.

Output:

emp_id name dept salary 1 Alice HR 50000 2 Bob IT 60000 3 Charlie HR 55000

docs.title: Q8: Employees NOT in HR
docs.text:
SELECT *
FROM employees
WHERE NOT dept = 'HR';

Explanation: NOT inverts the condition.

Output:

emp_id name dept salary 2 Bob IT 60000 4 David Sales 45000

docs.title: Q9: Employees in IT AND salary >= 60000
docs.text:
SELECT name, dept, salary
FROM employees
WHERE dept = 'IT' AND salary >= 60000;

Explanation: Both conditions must be true.

Output:

name dept salary Bob IT 60000

docs.title: Q10: Employees in Sales OR HR with salary < 50000
docs.text:
SELECT *
FROM employees
WHERE (dept = 'Sales' OR dept = 'HR') AND salary < 50000;

Explanation: Parentheses control precedence: OR is evaluated first.

Output:

emp_id name dept salary 4 David Sales 45000

docs.title: Q11: Employees with salary BETWEEN 50000 AND 60000
docs.text:
SELECT *
FROM employees
WHERE salary BETWEEN 50000 AND 60000;

Explanation: BETWEEN includes the boundary values.

Output:

emp_id name dept salary 1 Alice HR 50000 3 Charlie HR 55000 2 Bob IT 60000

docs.title: Q12: Employees in specific departments (IN)
docs.text:
SELECT *
FROM employees
WHERE dept IN ('HR', 'Sales');

Explanation: IN filters multiple discrete values.

Output:

emp_id name dept salary 1 Alice HR 50000 3 Charlie HR 55000 4 David Sales 45000

docs.title: Q13: Employees whose name starts with 'A' (LIKE)
docs.text:
SELECT *
FROM employees
WHERE name LIKE 'A%';

Explanation: % is wildcard for any number of characters.

Output:

emp_id name dept salary 1 Alice HR 50000

docs.title: Q14: Employees whose name contains 'a' (LIKE)
docs.text:
SELECT *
FROM employees
WHERE name LIKE '%a%';

Explanation: % before and after 'a' matches any string containing 'a'.

Output:

emp_id name dept salary 1 Alice HR 50000 2 Bob IT 60000 3 Charlie HR 55000 4 David Sales 45000

docs.title: Q15: Employees whose name ends with 'e'
docs.text:
SELECT *
FROM employees
WHERE name LIKE '%e';

Output:

emp_id name dept salary 1 Alice HR 50000 3 Charlie HR 55000

docs.title: Q16: Employees with NULL salary
docs.text:
Input Table: employees

emp_id name dept salary 1 Alice HR 50000 2 Bob IT NULL 3 Charlie HR 55000 4 David Sales NULL

Query:

SELECT *
FROM employees
WHERE salary IS NULL;

Explanation: IS NULL selects rows where value is NULL.

Output:

emp_id name dept salary 2 Bob IT NULL 4 David Sales NULL

docs.title: Q17: Employees with NOT NULL salary
docs.text:
SELECT *
FROM employees
WHERE salary IS NOT NULL;

Output:

emp_id name dept salary 1 Alice HR 50000 3 Charlie HR 55000

docs.title: Q18: Employees with salary NULL or less than 50000
docs.text:
SELECT *
FROM employees
WHERE salary IS NULL OR salary < 50000;

Output:

emp_id name dept salary 2 Bob IT NULL 4 David Sales NULL

docs.title: Q19: Employees with salary NOT NULL AND > 50000
docs.text:
SELECT *
FROM employees
WHERE salary IS NOT NULL AND salary > 50000;

Output:

emp_id name dept salary 2 Bob IT 60000 3 Charlie HR 55000

docs.title: Q20: Employees with salary IS NULL OR department = 'HR'
docs.text:
SELECT *
FROM employees
WHERE salary IS NULL OR dept = 'HR';

Output:

emp_id name dept salary 1 Alice HR 50000 2 Bob IT NULL 3 Charlie HR 55000

docs.title: SQL Practice: Functions (String, Date, Numeric) with Explanations
docs.text:
This file contains 20 SQL practice problems covering:

  • String functions: TRIM, SUBSTR, CONCAT, LENGTH, UPPER, LOWER
  • Date functions: NOW, GETDATE, DATEADD, DATEDIFF, TO_DATE
  • Numeric functions: ROUND, CEIL, FLOOR, ABS

Each question includes:

  • Input Table(s)
  • Question
  • SQL Query
  • Explanation
  • Output Table

docs.title: Q1: Remove spaces from names using TRIM
docs.text:
Input Table: employees

emp_id name 1 ' Alice ' 2 ' Bob ' 3 ' Charlie '

Query:

SELECT emp_id, TRIM(name) AS name_clean
FROM employees;

Explanation: TRIM removes leading and trailing spaces.

Output:

emp_id name_clean 1 Alice 2 Bob 3 Charlie

docs.title: Q2: Extract first 3 letters of name using SUBSTR
docs.text:
Input Table: employees

emp_id name 1 Alice 2 Bob 3 Charlie 
SELECT emp_id, SUBSTR(name,1,3) AS short_name
FROM employees;

Output:

emp_id short_name 1 Ali 2 Bob 3 Cha

docs.title: Q3: Concatenate name with department
docs.text:
Input Table: employees

emp_id name dept 1 Alice HR 2 Bob IT 3 Charlie Sales 
SELECT emp_id, CONCAT(name, ' - ', dept) AS name_dept
FROM employees;

Output:

emp_id name_dept 1 Alice - HR 2 Bob - IT 3 Charlie - Sales

docs.title: Q4: Get length of each name
docs.text:
Input Table: employees

emp_id name 1 Alice 2 Bob 3 Charlie 
SELECT emp_id, LENGTH(name) AS name_length
FROM employees;

Output:

emp_id name_length 1 5 2 3 3 7

docs.title: Q5: Convert name to uppercase and lowercase
docs.text:
Input Table: employees

emp_id name 1 Alice 2 Bob 3 Charlie 
SELECT emp_id, UPPER(name) AS upper_name, LOWER(name) AS lower_name
FROM employees;

Output:

emp_id upper_name lower_name 1 ALICE alice 2 BOB bob 3 CHARLIE charlie

docs.title: Q6: Get current date using NOW (MySQL) / GETDATE (SQL Server)
docs.text:
SELECT NOW() AS current_date; -- MySQL
-- SELECT GETDATE() AS current_date; -- SQL Server

Output Example:

current_date 2025-09-20 11:00

docs.title: Q7: Add 5 days to current date
docs.text:
SELECT DATEADD(day, 5, GETDATE()) AS future_date; -- SQL Server

Output Example:

future_date 2025-09-25 11:00

docs.title: Q8: Difference between two dates (in days)
docs.text:
Input Table: projects

project_id start_date end_date 1 2025-09-01 2025-09-10 2 2025-09-05 2025-09-20 
SELECT project_id, DATEDIFF(day, start_date, end_date) AS duration_days
FROM projects; -- SQL Server

Output:

project_id duration_days 1 9 2 15

docs.title: Q9: Convert string to date using TO_DATE (Oracle)
docs.text:
SELECT TO_DATE('20-09-2025','DD-MM-YYYY') AS date_val FROM dual;

Output:

date_val 20-SEP-25

docs.title: Q10: Extract year, month from date
docs.text:
Input Table: employees

emp_id name joining_date 1 Alice 2020-05-10 2 Bob 2021-08-15 3 Charlie 2022-01-20 
SELECT emp_id, YEAR(joining_date) AS year_joined, MONTH(joining_date) AS month_joined
FROM employees;

Output:

emp_id year_joined month_joined 1 2020 5 2 2021 8 3 2022 1

docs.title: Q11: Round salary to nearest 1000
docs.text:
Input Table: employees

emp_id salary 1 52345 2 60789 3 55432 
SELECT emp_id, ROUND(salary, -3) AS rounded_salary
FROM employees;

Output:

emp_id rounded_salary 1 52000 2 61000 3 55000

docs.title: Q12: Ceiling function
docs.text:
SELECT emp_id, CEIL(salary/1000.0) AS ceil_k_salary
FROM employees;

Output:

emp_id ceil_k_salary 1 53 2 61 3 56

docs.title: Q13: Floor function
docs.text:
SELECT emp_id, FLOOR(salary/1000.0) AS floor_k_salary
FROM employees;

Output:

emp_id floor_k_salary 1 52 2 60 3 55

docs.title: Q14: Absolute value
docs.text:
Input Table: transactions

trans_id amount 1 -500 2 300 3 -1000 
SELECT trans_id, ABS(amount) AS abs_amount
FROM transactions;

Output:

trans_id abs_amount 1 500 2 300 3 1000

docs.title: Q15: Multiply salary by 1.1 and round
docs.text:
SELECT emp_id, ROUND(salary*1.1,0) AS increased_salary
FROM employees;

Output:

emp_id increased_salary 1 57579 2 66868 3 60975

docs.title: Q16: Add 7 days to date using DATEADD
docs.text:
SELECT emp_id, DATEADD(day,7,joining_date) AS next_week
FROM employees;

Output:

emp_id next_week 1 2020-05-17 2 2021-08-22 3 2022-01-27

docs.title: Q17: Difference in years from today
docs.text:
SELECT emp_id, DATEDIFF(year, joining_date, GETDATE()) AS years_with_company
FROM employees;

Output Example:

emp_id years_with_company 1 5 2 4 3 3

docs.title: Q18: Concatenate numeric and string
docs.text:
SELECT emp_id, CONCAT('Salary: ', salary) AS salary_text
FROM employees;

Output:

emp_id salary_text 1 Salary: 52345 2 Salary: 60789 3 Salary: 55432

docs.title: Q19: Lowercase department
docs.text:
Input Table: employees

emp_id dept 1 HR 2 IT 3 Sales 
SELECT emp_id, LOWER(dept) AS lower_dept
FROM employees;

Output:

emp_id lower_dept 1 hr 2 it 3 sales

docs.title: Q20: Uppercase department
docs.text:
SELECT emp_id, UPPER(dept) AS upper_dept
FROM employees;

Output:

emp_id upper_dept 1 HR 2 IT 3 SALES

docs.title: SQL Practice: Joins with Explanations
docs.text:
This file contains 20 SQL practice problems covering:

  • INNER JOIN
  • LEFT JOIN
  • RIGHT JOIN
  • FULL OUTER JOIN
  • SELF JOIN

Each question includes:

  • Input Table(s)
  • Question
  • SQL Query
  • Explanation
  • Output Table

docs.title: Q1: Employees with their department names
docs.text:
Input Tables: employees

emp_id name dept_id 1 Alice 10 2 Bob 20 3 Charlie 30

departments

dept_id dept_name 10 HR 20 IT 30 Sales 40 Marketing

Query:

SELECT e.emp_id, e.name, d.dept_name
FROM employees e
INNER JOIN departments d ON e.dept_id = d.dept_id;

Explanation: INNER JOIN returns rows where there is a match in both tables.

Output:

emp_id name dept_name 1 Alice HR 2 Bob IT 3 Charlie Sales

docs.title: Q2: Employees with salary > 50000 and their departments
docs.text:
Input Table: salaries

emp_id salary 1 50000 2 60000 3 55000 
SELECT e.name, s.salary, d.dept_name
FROM employees e
INNER JOIN salaries s ON e.emp_id = s.emp_id
INNER JOIN departments d ON e.dept_id = d.dept_id
WHERE s.salary > 50000;

Output:

name salary dept_name Bob 60000 IT Charlie 55000 Sales

docs.title: Q3: Employees who have a project assigned
docs.text:
Input Table: projects

project_id emp_id project_name 101 1 Alpha 102 3 Beta 
SELECT e.name, p.project_name
FROM employees e
INNER JOIN projects p ON e.emp_id = p.emp_id;

Output:

name project_name Alice Alpha Charlie Beta

docs.title: Q4: Employees with matching departments (example with missing dept)
docs.text:
Input Table: employees same as above, departments without dept_id 30

dept_id dept_name 10 HR 20 IT 40 Marketing 
SELECT e.name, d.dept_name
FROM employees e
INNER JOIN departments d ON e.dept_id = d.dept_id;

Output:

name dept_name Alice HR Bob IT

docs.title: Q5: Inner join on multiple conditions
docs.text:
Input Table: employee_projects

emp_id project_id role 1 101 Developer 2 102 Manager 
SELECT e.name, ep.role, p.project_name
FROM employees e
INNER JOIN employee_projects ep ON e.emp_id = ep.emp_id
INNER JOIN projects p ON ep.project_id = p.project_id;

Output:

name role project_name Alice Developer Alpha Bob Manager Beta

docs.title: Q6: All employees and their departments (include those without dept)
docs.text:
Input Tables: employees and departments

SELECT e.name, d.dept_name
FROM employees e
LEFT JOIN departments d ON e.dept_id = d.dept_id;

Explanation: LEFT JOIN returns all rows from left table (employees), NULL if no match in right table.

Output:

name dept_name Alice HR Bob IT Charlie Sales

docs.title: Q7: Employees with projects (include those without projects)
docs.text:
Query:

SELECT e.name, p.project_name
FROM employees e
LEFT JOIN projects p ON e.emp_id = p.emp_id;

Output:

name project_name Alice Alpha Bob NULL Charlie Beta

docs.title: Q8: Left join with condition
docs.text:
SELECT e.name, s.salary
FROM employees e
LEFT JOIN salaries s ON e.emp_id = s.emp_id
WHERE s.salary > 50000 OR s.salary IS NULL;

Output:

name salary Alice 50000 Bob 60000 Charlie 55000

docs.title: Q9: Left join multiple tables
docs.text:
SELECT e.name, d.dept_name, p.project_name
FROM employees e
LEFT JOIN departments d ON e.dept_id = d.dept_id
LEFT JOIN projects p ON e.emp_id = p.emp_id;

Output:

name dept_name project_name Alice HR Alpha Bob IT NULL Charlie Sales Beta

docs.title: Q10: Left join with filtering
docs.text:
SELECT e.name, d.dept_name
FROM employees e
LEFT JOIN departments d ON e.dept_id = d.dept_id
WHERE d.dept_name IS NULL;

Output:

name dept_name (none if all matched)

docs.title: Q11: All departments and employees (include depts without employees)
docs.text:
SELECT e.name, d.dept_name
FROM employees e
RIGHT JOIN departments d ON e.dept_id = d.dept_id;

Output:

name dept_name Alice HR Bob IT Charlie Sales NULL Marketing

docs.title: Q12: Right join with projects
docs.text:
SELECT e.name, p.project_name
FROM employees e
RIGHT JOIN projects p ON e.emp_id = p.emp_id;

Output:

name project_name Alice Alpha Charlie Beta

docs.title: Q13: Right join multiple tables
docs.text:
SELECT e.name, s.salary, d.dept_name
FROM employees e
RIGHT JOIN salaries s ON e.emp_id = s.emp_id
RIGHT JOIN departments d ON e.dept_id = d.dept_id;

Output:

name salary dept_name Alice 50000 HR Bob 60000 IT Charlie 55000 Sales NULL NULL Marketing

docs.title: Q14: Right join with condition
docs.text:
SELECT e.name, d.dept_name
FROM employees e
RIGHT JOIN departments d ON e.dept_id = d.dept_id
WHERE e.name IS NULL;

Output:

name dept_name NULL Marketing

docs.title: Q15: Right join with filtering on NULL
docs.text:
SELECT e.name, p.project_name
FROM employees e
RIGHT JOIN projects p ON e.emp_id = p.emp_id
WHERE e.name IS NULL;

Output:

name project_name (none)

docs.title: Q16: Employees and departments (all records)
docs.text:
SELECT e.name, d.dept_name
FROM employees e
FULL OUTER JOIN departments d ON e.dept_id = d.dept_id;

Output:

name dept_name Alice HR Bob IT Charlie Sales NULL Marketing

docs.title: Q17: Employees and projects (all records)
docs.text:
SELECT e.name, p.project_name
FROM employees e
FULL OUTER JOIN projects p ON e.emp_id = p.emp_id;

Output:

name project_name Alice Alpha Bob NULL Charlie Beta

docs.title: Q18: Full join with multiple tables
docs.text:
SELECT e.name, d.dept_name, p.project_name
FROM employees e
FULL OUTER JOIN departments d ON e.dept_id = d.dept_id
FULL OUTER JOIN projects p ON e.emp_id = p.emp_id;

Output:

name dept_name project_name Alice HR Alpha Bob IT NULL Charlie Sales Beta NULL Marketing NULL

docs.title: Q19: Employees and their manager (self join)
docs.text:
Input Table: employees

emp_id name manager_id 1 Alice NULL 2 Bob 1 3 Charlie 1 
SELECT e1.name AS employee, e2.name AS manager
FROM employees e1
LEFT JOIN employees e2 ON e1.manager_id = e2.emp_id;

Output:

employee manager Alice NULL Bob Alice Charlie Alice

docs.title: Q20: Employees reporting to the same manager
docs.text:
SELECT e1.name AS emp1, e2.name AS emp2, e1.manager_id
FROM employees e1
INNER JOIN employees e2 ON e1.manager_id = e2.manager_id
WHERE e1.emp_id < e2.emp_id;

Output:

emp1 emp2 manager_id Bob Charlie 1

docs.title: SQL Practice: Set Operators with Explanations
docs.text:
This file contains 15 SQL practice problems covering:

  • UNION / UNION ALL
  • INTERSECT
  • MINUS / EXCEPT

Each question includes:

  • Input Table(s)
  • Question
  • SQL Query
  • Explanation
  • Output Table

docs.title: Q1: Combine employees from two departments
docs.text:
Input Tables: dept_hr

emp_id name 1 Alice 2 Bob

dept_it

emp_id name 3 Charlie 4 David

Query:

SELECT name FROM dept_hr
UNION
SELECT name FROM dept_it;

Explanation: UNION combines results and removes duplicates.

Output:

name Alice Bob Charlie David

docs.title: Q2: UNION ALL (keep duplicates)
docs.text:
Input Tables: dept_sales

emp_id name 5 Eve 6 Frank

dept_marketing

emp_id name 6 Frank 7 Grace 
SELECT name FROM dept_sales
UNION ALL
SELECT name FROM dept_marketing;

Output:

name Eve Frank Frank Grace

docs.title: Q3: Employees present in both departments
docs.text:
Input Tables: dept_a

emp_id name 1 Alice 2 Bob 3 Charlie

dept_b

emp_id name 2 Bob 3 Charlie 4 David 
SELECT name FROM dept_a
INTERSECT
SELECT name FROM dept_b;

Explanation: INTERSECT returns only rows present in both tables.

Output:

name Bob Charlie

docs.title: Q4: INTERSECT multiple conditions
docs.text:
SELECT emp_id, name FROM dept_a
INTERSECT
SELECT emp_id, name FROM dept_b;

Output:

emp_id name 2 Bob 3 Charlie

docs.title: Q5: Employees in dept_a but not in dept_b
docs.text:
SELECT name FROM dept_a
MINUS
SELECT name FROM dept_b; -- Oracle
-- EXCEPT in SQL Server

Output:

name Alice

docs.title: Q6: Employees in dept_b but not in dept_a
docs.text:
SELECT name FROM dept_b
MINUS
SELECT name FROM dept_a;

Output:

name David

docs.title: Q7: UNION and MINUS combined
docs.text:
Input Tables: dept_x

emp_id name 1 Alice 2 Bob

dept_y

emp_id name 2 Bob 3 Charlie 
SELECT name FROM (
  SELECT name FROM dept_x
  UNION
  SELECT name FROM dept_y
) combined
MINUS
SELECT name FROM dept_x;

Explanation: Combine both tables, then remove names already in dept_x.

Output:

name Charlie

docs.title: Q8: Check mismatched records between source and target
docs.text:
Input Tables: source_employees

emp_id name 1 Alice 2 Bob 3 Charlie

target_employees

emp_id name 2 Bob 3 Charlie 4 David 
SELECT name FROM source_employees
MINUS
SELECT name FROM target_employees;

Output:

name Alice

docs.title: Q9: EXCEPT example (SQL Server)
docs.text:
SELECT name FROM target_employees
EXCEPT
SELECT name FROM source_employees;

Output:

name David

docs.title: Q10: Find common employees and unique employees in one query
docs.text:
SELECT name FROM source_employees
INTERSECT
SELECT name FROM target_employees; -- common

SELECT name FROM source_employees
MINUS
SELECT name FROM target_employees; -- in source only

SELECT name FROM target_employees
MINUS
SELECT name FROM source_employees; -- in target only

Output: Common:

name Bob Charlie

Source only:

name Alice

Target only:

name David

docs.title: SQL Practice: Subqueries (Single-row, Multi-row, Correlated) with Explanations
docs.text:
This file contains 20 SQL practice problems covering:

  • Single-row subquery (=, <, >)
  • Multi-row subquery (IN, ANY, ALL)
  • Correlated subquery

Each question includes:

  • Input Table(s)
  • Question
  • SQL Query
  • Explanation
  • Output Table

docs.title: Q1: Find employees with salary equal to the highest salary
docs.text:
Input Table: employees

emp_id name salary 1 Alice 48000 2 Bob 60000 3 Charlie 55000 4 David 45000 5 Eva 70000 
SELECT emp_id, name, salary
FROM employees
WHERE salary = (SELECT MAX(salary) FROM employees);

Explanation: Single-row subquery returns MAX(salary). The outer query selects employee(s) with that salary.

Output:

emp_id name salary 5 Eva 70000

docs.title: Q2: Employees with salary less than the average salary
docs.text:
SELECT emp_id, name, salary
FROM employees
WHERE salary < (SELECT AVG(salary) FROM employees);

docs.title: Q3: Employee(s) with minimum salary

FROM employees
WHERE salary = (SELECT MIN(salary) FROM employees);

FROM employees

FROM employees
WHERE dept IN (
    SELECT dept
    FROM employees
    GROUP BY dept
    HAVING COUNT(*) > 1
);

Explanation: Multi-row subquery returns departments with more than 1 employee. Outer query selects employees in those departments.

Output:

docs.title: Q7: Employees with salary in top 3 salaries

Output:

docs.title: Q8: Employees in departments 'HR' or 'IT'

Output:

docs.title: Q9: Employees not in department with only one employee

docs.title: SQL Practice: Aggregations (GROUP BY, Aggregate Functions, HAVING) with Explanations
docs.text:
This file contains 20 SQL practice problems covering:

  • GROUP BY
  • Aggregate functions: COUNT, SUM, AVG, MIN, MAX
  • HAVING clause

Each question includes:

  • Input Table(s)
  • Question
  • SQL Query
  • Explanation
  • Output Table

docs.title: Q1: Count employees in each department
docs.text:
Input Table: employees

emp_id name dept 1 Alice HR 2 Bob IT 3 Charlie HR 4 David IT 5 Eva Sales 
SELECT dept, COUNT(*) AS emp_count
FROM employees
GROUP BY dept;

Explanation: COUNT(*) counts rows in each department.

Output:

dept emp_count HR 2 IT 2 Sales 1

docs.title: Q2: Count employees with salary > 50000 in each department
docs.text:
Input Table: employees

emp_id name dept salary 1 Alice HR 48000 2 Bob IT 60000 3 Charlie HR 55000 4 David IT 45000 5 Eva Sales 70000 
SELECT dept, COUNT(*) AS emp_count_high_salary
FROM employees
WHERE salary > 50000
GROUP BY dept;

Output:

dept emp_count_high_salary HR 1 IT 1 Sales 1

docs.title: Q3: Count distinct departments
docs.text:

FROM employees;

docs.title: Q4: Count employees per department having more than 1 employee

FROM employees

HAVING COUNT(*) > 1;

docs.title: Q5: Count employees whose name starts with 'A' per department

SELECT dept, COUNT(*) AS count_A

docs.title: Data Query Language (DQL) – Part 4: Subqueries & CTE (WITH)
docs.text: This part dives into Subqueries and CTEs (Common Table Expressions) with 6 core examples and 3 complex cases. Each example shows input tables, the SQL query, and the expected output.

docs.title: Employees
docs.text: EmpID Name DeptID Salary ManagerID 101 Amit Sharma 1 50000 nan 102 Riya Mehta 2 70000 101 103 Arjun Rao 3 55000 101 104 Neha Singh 2 80000 102 105 Rohit Verma 1 48000 101 106 Priya Nair 2 65000 102

docs.title: Departments
docs.text: DeptID DeptName 1 HR 2 IT 3 Finance 4 Marketing

docs.title: OrderItems
docs.text: OrderID Product Qty UnitPrice 1 Laptop 1 60000 1 Mouse 2 1000 2 Tablet 3 15000 3 Laptop 1 60000 3 Phone 2 20000 4 Phone 1 20000 5 Laptop 1 60000 6 Mouse 5 1000

docs.title: 1) Scalar Subquery – Employees earning above company average
docs.text:
SELECT EmpID, Name, Salary
FROM Employees
WHERE Salary > (SELECT AVG(Salary) FROM Employees)
ORDER BY Salary DESC;

Output | EmpID | Name | Salary | |--------:|:-----------|---------:| | 104 | Neha Singh | 80000 | | 102 | Riya Mehta | 70000 | | 106 | Priya Nair | 65000 |

docs.title: 2) IN Subquery – Employees in departments having more than 1 employee
docs.text:
SELECT e.EmpID, e.Name, e.DeptID, d.DeptName
FROM Employees e
JOIN Departments d ON e.DeptID = d.DeptID
WHERE e.DeptID IN (
  SELECT DeptID
  FROM Employees
  GROUP BY DeptID
  HAVING COUNT(*) > 1
)
ORDER BY e.DeptID, e.Name;

Output | EmpID | Name | DeptID | DeptName | |--------:|:------------|---------:|:-----------| | 101 | Amit Sharma | 1 | HR | | 105 | Rohit Verma | 1 | HR | | 104 | Neha Singh | 2 | IT | | 106 | Priya Nair | 2 | IT | | 102 | Riya Mehta | 2 | IT |

docs.title: 3) EXISTS (Correlated) – Employees who have placed at least one order
docs.text:
SELECT e.EmpID, e.Name
FROM Employees e
WHERE EXISTS (
  SELECT 1
  FROM Orders o
  WHERE o.EmpID = e.EmpID
)
ORDER BY e.EmpID;

Output | EmpID | Name | |--------:|:-----------| | 102 | Riya Mehta | | 103 | Arjun Rao | | 104 | Neha Singh | | 106 | Priya Nair |

docs.title: 4) NOT EXISTS – Departments with no employees
docs.text:
SELECT d.DeptID, d.DeptName
FROM Departments d
WHERE NOT EXISTS (
  SELECT 1
  FROM Employees e
  WHERE e.DeptID = d.DeptID
)
ORDER BY d.DeptID;

Output | DeptID | DeptName | |---------:|:-----------| | 4 | Marketing |

docs.title: 5) Subquery in FROM (Derived Table) – Revenue by product
docs.text:
SELECT t.Product, t.TotalRevenue
FROM (
  SELECT oi.Product,
         SUM(oi.Qty * oi.UnitPrice) AS TotalRevenue
  FROM OrderItems oi
  GROUP BY oi.Product
) AS t
ORDER BY t.TotalRevenue DESC;

Output | Product | TotalRevenue | |:----------|---------------:| | Laptop | 180000 | | Phone | 60000 | | Tablet | 45000 | | Mouse | 7000 |

docs.title: 6) ANY/ALL – Salary greater than ALL salaries in HR
docs.text:
SELECT Name, Salary
FROM Employees
WHERE Salary > ALL (
  SELECT Salary FROM Employees WHERE DeptID = 1
)
ORDER BY Salary DESC;

Output | Name | Salary | |:-----------|---------:| | Neha Singh | 80000 | | Riya Mehta | 70000 | | Priya Nair | 65000 | | Arjun Rao | 55000 |

docs.title: 7) CTE – Revenue per employee
docs.text:
WITH OrderTotals AS (
  SELECT oi.OrderID, SUM(oi.Qty * oi.UnitPrice) AS OrderTotal
  FROM OrderItems oi
  GROUP BY oi.OrderID
)
SELECT e.Name, SUM(ot.OrderTotal) AS Revenue
FROM Orders o
JOIN OrderTotals ot ON o.OrderID = ot.OrderID
JOIN Employees e ON o.EmpID = e.EmpID
GROUP BY e.Name
ORDER BY Revenue DESC;

Output | Name | Revenue | |:-----------|----------:| | Riya Mehta | 162000 | | Arjun Rao | 60000 | | Neha Singh | 45000 | | Priya Nair | 25000 |

docs.title: 8) Multiple CTEs – Per-customer orders & revenue
docs.text:
WITH OrderTotals AS (
  SELECT oi.OrderID, SUM(oi.Qty * oi.UnitPrice) AS OrderTotal
  FROM OrderItems oi
  GROUP BY oi.OrderID
),
CustomerOrders AS (
  SELECT o.Customer, o.OrderID, ot.OrderTotal
  FROM Orders o
  JOIN OrderTotals ot ON o.OrderID = ot.OrderID
)
SELECT Customer,
       COUNT(DISTINCT OrderID) AS Orders,
       SUM(OrderTotal)         AS Revenue
FROM CustomerOrders
GROUP BY Customer
ORDER BY Revenue DESC;

Output | Customer | Orders | Revenue | |:-----------|---------:|----------:| | Crown | 1 | 100000 | | Acme | 3 | 87000 | | Delta | 1 | 60000 | | Bolt | 1 | 45000 |

docs.title: 9) Recursive CTE – Organization levels
docs.text:
WITH RECURSIVE Org AS (
  SELECT EmpID, Name, ManagerID, 0 AS Level
  FROM Employees
  WHERE ManagerID IS NULL
  UNION ALL
  SELECT e.EmpID, e.Name, e.ManagerID, o.Level + 1
  FROM Employees e
  JOIN Org o ON e.ManagerID = o.EmpID
)
SELECT EmpID, Name, Level
FROM Org
ORDER BY Level, EmpID;

Output | EmpID | Name | Level | |--------:|:------------|--------:| | 101 | Amit Sharma | 0 | | 102 | Riya Mehta | 1 | | 103 | Arjun Rao | 1 | | 105 | Rohit Verma | 1 | | 104 | Neha Singh | 2 | | 106 | Priya Nair | 2 |

docs.title: Complex A) Top 2 earners per department (CTE + window function)
docs.text:
WITH Ranked AS (
  SELECT d.DeptName, e.Name, e.Salary,
         ROW_NUMBER() OVER (PARTITION BY e.DeptID ORDER BY e.Salary DESC) AS rn
  FROM Employees e
  LEFT JOIN Departments d ON e.DeptID = d.DeptID
)
SELECT DeptName, Name, Salary, rn AS Rank
FROM Ranked
WHERE rn <= 2
ORDER BY DeptName, Rank, Name;

Output | DeptName | Name | Salary | Rank | |:-----------|:------------|---------:|-------:| | Finance | Arjun Rao | 55000 | 1 | | HR | Amit Sharma | 50000 | 1 | | HR | Rohit Verma | 48000 | 2 | | IT | Neha Singh | 80000 | 1 | | IT | Riya Mehta | 70000 | 2 |

docs.title: Complex B) Highest revenue product per customer (CTE + ranking)
docs.text:
WITH CustProd AS (
  SELECT o.Customer, oi.Product,
         SUM(oi.Qty * oi.UnitPrice) AS Revenue
  FROM Orders o
  JOIN OrderItems oi ON o.OrderID = oi.OrderID
  GROUP BY o.Customer, oi.Product
),
Ranked AS (
  SELECT Customer, Product, Revenue,
         ROW_NUMBER() OVER (PARTITION BY Customer ORDER BY Revenue DESC) AS rk
  FROM CustProd
)
SELECT Customer, Product, Revenue
FROM Ranked
WHERE rk = 1
ORDER BY Customer;

Output | Customer | Product | Revenue | |:-----------|:----------|----------:| | Acme | Laptop | 60000 | | Bolt | Tablet | 45000 | | Crown | Laptop | 60000 | | Delta | Laptop | 60000 |

docs.title: Complex C) Manager → Employee pairs (recursive CTE for relationships)
docs.text:
WITH RECURSIVE Tree AS (
  SELECT EmpID, Name, ManagerID, CAST(Name AS VARCHAR(200)) AS Path
  FROM Employees
  WHERE ManagerID IS NULL
  UNION ALL
  SELECT e.EmpID, e.Name, e.ManagerID, CAST(t.Path || ' > ' || e.Name AS VARCHAR(200))
  FROM Employees e
  JOIN Tree t ON e.ManagerID = t.EmpID
)
SELECT * FROM Tree ORDER BY Path;

Output | Manager | Employee | |:------------|:------------| | Amit Sharma | Arjun Rao | | Amit Sharma | Riya Mehta | | Amit Sharma | Rohit Verma | | Riya Mehta | Neha Singh | | Riya Mehta | Priya Nair |

✅ In this part, you learned: - Scalar, IN, EXISTS/NOT EXISTS, ANY/ALL subqueries - Derived tables (subquery in FROM) - CTEs (single, multiple) and recursive CTEs for hierarchies - Complex patterns using window functions + CTEs

docs.title: 🔹 What is TCL?
docs.text: TCL commands manage transactions in the database. They ensure data integrity and control how changes are saved or undone.

docs.title: 1. COMMIT
docs.text:
• Saves changes permanently.
COMMIT;

docs.title: 2. ROLLBACK
docs.text:
• Undo changes since last commit.
ROLLBACK;

docs.title: 3. SAVEPOINT
docs.text:
• Creates a point to rollback partially.
SAVEPOINT sp1;
ROLLBACK TO sp1;

docs.title: 4. SET TRANSACTION
docs.text:
• Sets transaction properties like isolation level.
SET TRANSACTION READ ONLY;

docs.title: ✅ Pros
docs.text:
1. Transaction Safety → Prevents accidental data loss.
